title: mp second job rich list
story: MP second job rich list - Tories raking in up to £.m each ON TOP of salaryTheresa May, Sir Geoffrey Cox, Sir John Redwood and Fiona Bruce are among the MPs with staggering incomes from consultancy roles, book deals and speechesByGeraldine McKelvieInvestigations EditorMikey SmithWhitehall CorrespondentDan Hall:,  Nov Updated:,  Nov | comments The resignation of former Tory minister Owen Paterson has thrown the issue of MPs’ incomes into the spotlight.Mr Paterson last week dramatically quit as North Shropshire MP after being accused of lobbying on behalf of Randox and Lynn’s Foods - who have together paid him more than £, as a consultant.He denies any wrongdoing - but says the “intolerable” pressure on his family meant he couldn’t continue in politics.Many MPs have other income streams, making money from things like consultancy roles, book deals and speeches. There is no cap on what MPs can earn on top of their parliamentary salary - which starts at £, excluding expenses and other perks - provided that all income is declared in official registers and no work relates to lobbying parliament. But this rule is controversial - with some politicians and campaign groups arguing MPs shouldn’t be allowed to take on any other paid work. We analysed the Commons register of financial interests to see which ten MPs have declared the largest earnings from the private sector since the  election. . Theresa May- £.m Unlike her predecessor David Cameron, the former Prime Minister refused to give up her Maidenhead seat when she was forced out of office in July .She signed to the prestigious Washington Speakers Bureau later that year and, on average, she declares  times as much a year from talks as she earns as a backbencher. In February , she was paid £, to speak to a women’s forum founded by the Dubai ruler Sheikh Mohammed bin Rashid Al Maktoum despite ongoing international concern about the UAEaposs human rights record. During her visit, May was pictured shaking the hand of Al Maktoum, who has been accused of kidnapping his daughters and abusing his estranged we. And the pandemic didnapost put a stop to her lucrative speaking gigs - during lockdown she was charging around £, for speeches delivered on Zoom.Mrs Mayaposs speaking earnings are paid to the Office of Theresa May Ltd.On the register of interests, she declares: These sums are used to pay employees, maintain my ongoing involvement in public le and support my charitable work. The Office of Theresa May has paid the former Prime Minister a salary of £, a year since September last year. . Sir Geoffrey Cox- £m  Former attorney general Sir Geoffrey Cox has made a fortune working as a barrister while representing Torridge and West Devon in parliament. And heaposs no stranger to controversy over his huge earnings. In , he resigned from the House of Commons standards committee when it was revealed he failed to meet the deadline for declaring £, he’d been paid for legal work. The committee found he had committed a serious breach of parliamentary rules but accepted it was not intentional and he made a public apology. In the same year, he unsuccessfully tried to claim p for a pint of milk on Commons expenses but this was rejected by the Independent Parliamentary Standards Authority. In response, he said: “In collating the office expenses for me to sign off, my staff had failed to notice that the rules had changed in May so as to place these costs outside the scope of IPSA’s scheme. “Once the error was identied, it was ed by Ipsa and immediately cancelled by my office.” He gave up practising law temporarily when he was appointed attorney general in , but has made more than a million since leaving the cabinet and resuming legal work in February . . Sir John Redwood- £k  Sir John Redwood, a former Tory leadership candidate and secretary of state for Wales, has several roles with private investment firms. The bulk of the Wokingham MP’s earnings come from his role as chairman of the investment committee of Charles Stanley - which has netted him £, per month since the last election. The firm also pays him bonuses on occasion. Despite his wealth, he once charged the taxpayer £ for reseeding the lawn at his constituency home in Berkshire. He was ordered to pay the money back - and moaned that the decision was unfair because he felt it was an honest and accurate claim. . Fiona Bruce- £k  Lawyer Fiona Bruce is the Prime Ministeraposs envoy on the human right to freedom of religion or belief. The Congleton MP has continued to work for her own Cheshire based firm, Fiona Bruce and Co LLP, since being elected in . Ms Bruce said the four largest of the  payments she listed were “almost entirely tax payments not receipts by me” but “for technical reasons have to be declared.” . Andrew Mitchell- £k  Former international development secretary Andrew Mitchell makes a tidy sum from private investment companies while representing Sutton Coldfield in parliament. This includes SouthBridge, an African investment bank based which pays him £, a year for just nine days’ work. Yet in the past some of his expense claims have raised eyebrows. When thebroke the story of the MPs’ expenses scandal in , it was revealed heaposd claimed £, for cleaning, decorating and gardening - even billing the public purse for a duvet stuffed with goose down. He told the paper he’d acted within the rules, insisting the sum claimed was “less than the cost that I have incurred maintaining my second home and is less than the amount I would have been entitled to claim. . Sajid Javid- £k The Bromsgrove MP resigned as chancellor in February  following an explosive bust up with Boris Johnsonaposs former top aide Dominic Cummings.But just months after leaving office, he was handed two roles with a combined annual salary of over £,. In August last year, he began a £, a year role with bank JP Morgan. Due to the fact heaposd served in the cabinet within the last two years, he had to consult the governmentaposs Advisory Committee on Business Appointments about his roles. The committee warned Javidaposs privileged access to information as chancellor meant accepting a job with JP Morgan carried potential risks but ultimately allowed the appointment to go ahead. Two months later, he signed up for a role with software firm C.ai, paying an annual salary of £,. He also consulted the committee about this role. In addition, he made money from speeches. He quit both JP Morgan and C.ai after less than a year, ing to the cabinet in June to replace Matt Hancock as health secretary. . Richard Fuller- £k Mr Fuller represented Bedford from  to , when he lost his seat to Labour, and took up a role as chief executive of software company Impero Solutions.He ed to parliament in  to represent North East Bedfordshire and quit his post with the company. Impero gave him a severance payment of £, at the end of March  - but allowed him to continue as an advisory director, paying £, a year for just two hours work a month. He also has a string of roles advising other firms, in the fields of software, security and venture capitalism. . Owen Paterson- £k  The MP at the centre of the furore made his money as a consultant to Randox and Lynnaposs Country Foods, netting him north of £, a year on top of his backbench salary. The former environment secretary refused to accept the standards committeeaposs findings that he had lobbied on behalf of both companies, in contravention of the rules. A government bid to reform the standards process - which would have allowed him to appeal - backfired. He resigned this week in the wake of the controversy, a decision which will trigger a by-election in his North Shropshire constituency. . Sir John Hayes- £k  The South Holland and the Deepings MP served in a range of ministerial posts under both Theresa May and David Cameron. Since leaving government in , he’s made money in a number of dferent ways. He has a lucrative contract as an advisor to oil company BB Energy paying £, a year. He also delivers lectures on political studies. . Nadine Dorries- £k  Culture secretary Nadine Dorries makes her money writing books on the side - mainly based in her home city of Liverpool - and has sold over . million to date. Sheaposs written  titles in total and regularly receives royalty payments, as well as advances for new work. Her first book was published in  - nine years after her election to parliament. news politics tory-mps-express-misery-over-"Owen Paterson: Aaron Bell discusses voting against governmentByAletha Adu:,  Nov Updated:,  Nov | commentsFrustrated Tory MPs from the  intake expressed their disappointment over Boris Johnsonapossapos handling of the sleaze scandal. Aaron Bell, the Tory MP for Newcastle-under-Lyme, said some Tories in the apos groupapos a nickname for the apos intake have been “beating themselves up” about siding with the Government. Mr Bell who opted to rebel on the matter, said his colleagues were put in an “invidious position” by the Government. “It churns you up beforehand and leaves you a little shell-shocked afterwards. Perhaps next time it will be easier.” And Tory MP Mark Fletcher, a member of the Standards Committee, urged people to not paint all Tories with the same brush as he insisted many are desperate to stay within the rules.Mr Fletcher told the Commons he would vote against the billhe had to today.  “I think that two years here is more than enough to know the dference between right and wrong, Mr Fletcher added. He urged the Government to avoid ordering Tory MPs to vote a certain way in future matters on standards, before thanking politicians on all sides for checking up on him following his decision to rebel. Their remarks appeared to show a deepening ide within the Tory party, with newer MPs expressing their fury over senior memberaposs handling of the Owen Paterson case. The Standards Committee had recommended former Tory cabinet minister Mr Paterson should be suspended from Parliament for  days after committing an “egregious” breach of a ban on paid lobbying by MPs.  But Mr Paterson quit Parliament before he could be suspended.Mr Bell even quoted a WhatsApp message sent by Tory MP Jill Mortimer, who was elected to represent Hartlepool in May. He told the House: “She said ‘this was a colossal misjudgement, it should not have been whipped, you should have been allowed to vote with your conscience on this’. “I couldn’t agree more and I hope the Treasury bench is listening. Let usto the convention where House business is not whipped.”  And former Tory chief whip Mark Harper urged Mr Johnson to demonstrate leadership and apologise in the Commons. He said: “I hope ministers can rule that out, I think that would be a mistake and most regrettable. “Theydeserve that decisions are well thought through and soundly based and , on occasion, as on this occasion…the team captain gets it wrong, then I think he should come and apologise to the public and to this House, that’s the right thing to do in terms of demonstrating leadership.” Labour leader Sir Keir Starmer slammed the PM for running scared.  He told the Commons: This week he had the chance to clean up, to apologise to the country and finally accept that the rules apply to him and his friends. “But instead of stepping up he has hidden away. Instead of clearing up his mess he has left his side knee-deep in it. Instead of leading from the front, he has cowered away. He is not a serious leader and the joke isn’t funny any more.”  Instead of making the apology on behalf of his party, Mr Johnson was pictured walking brazenly through a Northumbria hospital, maskless next to NHS staff who all wore face coverings. Number  insist Mr Johnson was following the rules and that he could not make it back to London in time for the debate. title: i spend 10p familys christmas
story: I spend p on my familys Christmas presents - and I start shopping in JanuaryVictoria Billington, , first started bargain hunting for her Christmas gts a few years ago when money was tight. Although she no longer has a budget, shes still shopping for cheaper options - to benefit the environmentVictoria has shared her top tips for having a frugal Christmas Image: PA Real LeByHarriet BulloughJessica TaylorReal le features writer:,  Nov Updated:,  Nov | commentsA bargain-hunting mum who has made it her mission to have a sustainable, low-budget Christmas admits she starts her festive shopping in January. Community worker Victoria Billington, , who lives with husband Simon and kids, five-year-old Teddy and three-year-old Elisabeth, has been bargain shopping for years. She first started looking for cheaper gt options a few years ago when money was tight and she had  nieces and nephews to buy for. In the past, the frugal mum has sted through books in charity shops to pick up novels for as little as p and even made a dollaposs house for £. In a bid to be as eco-friendly as possible, she also makes her own recyclable wrapping paper and reuses her homemade advent calendar every Christmas. She said: My husband and I used to be freelancers so we couldnapost always rely on how much income we were going to have at that time. For more of the news you care about straight to your inbox, sign up for one of our daily newsletters here So about five years ago, I started making a gt for each of the children on my list as it will be meaningful but wonapost cost anything. Now, it’s not really about the saving for us and more about being as eco-friendly as possible. She added that, of course, Christmas works out cheaper when sheaposs buying second-hand presents too, but she puts a lot of effort into carefully selecting each gt. Victoria, who has four sisters, said her family always valued thoughtful gts over expensive ones. My mum always said sheaposd rather have a bar of soap wrapped up than a really expensive present, she said. So we grew up with this idea of being generous at Christmas, but that doesnapost have to be extravagant.  In order to keep track of her bargains, Victoria has to be incredibly organised, and starts a checklist for all her recipients every year. I start as early as January, she said. I used to lose track when I started, so now I keep a list and write down what I’ve got everyone as I go. I really think about what each person wants. I don’t have a spend limit - I just try and make it meaningful to that person. Although she has no budget these days, Victoria still sets out to find bargains and scours charity shops for gts she thinks will suit her loved ones well. At some charity shops, you can get brand new, unread books for as little as p, she explained. So I grab a few of someone’s favourite books and their present costs me like p. I also found one of my nieces a doll that retails at £ for £, so Iaposm definitely saving a lot of money. Plus it saves any last-minute panic buying! After having kids, Victoria says she became much more aware of environmental issues around fast fashion and buying lots of new things all the time. “It broadens your horizon that itaposs not just about yourself. You start thinking, ‘What are we leaving for our children ’ “Iaposve always been quite thrty and Iaposve always looked to find a bargain. But especially in the last few years, Iaposve been thinking about where I spend my money. It made me realise charity shops and small businesses will benefit more from my spending as well as being more sustainable. As well as charity shops, Victoria finds gts on websites like Olio and Facebook Marketplace and often upcycling items to create cool gts.“I canapost draw so I wouldnapost call myself creative in that way,” she laughed.“I suppose I have the time. When I’m making things, I usually start with an open Google search to find out how to use a material or how to make a particular toy.“I got a lot of crafting supplies from Olio. I think for me that was one of my most exciting finds. Last year, Victoria bought a second hand dollaposs house for £ - and spent several weeks decorating it before gting it to her kids. She said: It was their big present so weaposd got it early and weaposd planned ahead so we were able to spend a while decorating it. Thereaposs tiny little bunting, made from paper and string, that we put on the walls. Victoria has a felt advent calendar that she reuses every year, putting chocolates and bad Christmas jokes in every day for the kids to enjoy. She also enlists hubby Simon to help making presents. Victoria said: My husband is actually very creative so he draws pictures that we can then frame and gt to people. We also make decorations out of pine cones. By just adding festive ribbon or felt greenery, you can make a wreath with a timeless Christmas feel. And none of their arty work is thrown away come January - instead it is carefully stored away in the airing cupboard in a reusable shopping bag, ready to use every Christmas. Although sheaposs proud of her eco-friendly traditions, Victoria doesnapost want to pressure other parents into copying her. I recognise I have the privilege of time,” she explained.Do you plan Christmas months in advance  Email jessica.taylor@reachplc“What we don’t spend in money, we do spend in time and I know not everyone has the ability to do that. “But for us it makes Christmas more special and itaposs really enjoyable to see everyone love the gts you’ve put so much time into. Victoria’s top tips for a sustainable Christmas * Don’t leave it too late – Get started early so you have plenty of time to look out for bargains. * Shop local – Reduce delivery and shipments by shopping in your local area. You don’t have to wait and can guarantee your presents will arrive on time. * Charity shops are great for a bargain – Many businesses donate brand new items to charity shops. Not only do you save money but the money you do spend goes to charity. * Watch how you wrap – Not all wrapping paper is recyclable and making your own can be a fun activity with the kids. Make it a family activity using stamps to create fun recyclable paper. * Don’t follow trends – You don’t need to change your decorations every year or follow the latest fad. Make decorations that are timeless that you can reuse every year. title: brecon beacons most tragic accidents
story: The pilot made a miraculous escape and walked away from the crash" content"https:i-prod.dailystar incoming article.ece ALTERNATES n _NEWSLINK_.jpg" width"" "" A light aircraft that crashed in the Brecon Beacons in the snowy weather Image: WALES NEWS SERVICEByHarry Thompson:,  Nov | comments A team thought to be made up of over  people are currently involved in a rescue effort to save a man who fell whilst caving in the Brecon Beacons. The man, who is thought to have fallen in the Ogof Ffynnon Ddu cave network near Penwyllt, has been trapped for two days having hurt his back.He has received medical treatment in the cave, and have been in contact with both the internationally renowned rescuers and other cavers.But this scary saga is far from the first crisis to take place in the Brecon Beacons, with a list of terrying accidents having befallen the sprawling mountainous national park. Where are the Brecon Beacons   Stretching from west to east Wales, the range is home to iconic mountains Pen y Fan, the Black Mountains, Dan yr Ogof all in a rugged and wild that in places seems devoid of human le. The range sits along the border of mid and south Wales, while the bigger still  square mile Snowdonia sits in the countryaposs north west. The  SAS tragedyIt comes as little surprise then that this expansive, remote landscape is the training ground of choice for the SAS Pen y Fan is notorious for its gruelling aposFan Danceapos hike, a  mile long walk used in the selection process for much of Britainaposs special forces.But the special forcesapos love affair with the Beacons is riddled with tragedy.  In  three soldiers - Corporal James Dunsby, , Lance Corporal Craig Roberts, , and Lance Corporal Edward Maher,  - undertaking the selection process to become SAS reservists died on a  mile exercise in the mountain range, leading to y investigations into whether there had been negligence on behalf of the SAS in protecting the men.Earlier this year the Mirror reported that as many  service people had died in the Beacons since , almost one every other year.But itaposs not just rigorous SAS training that have claimed lives people in  square mile park it has a terrible record for plane crashes. Canadians in the Second World War In , in the latter stages of the Second World War a bomber carrying six Canadian service men crashed at Carreg Goch - much of the debris from the crash can still be found around the area as can two plaques honouring the dead can be found in the area. Two years prior to that a Spitfire came down, killing fellow Canadian -year-old Sergeant Donald Perry Carruthers - it took nine days to recover his burned body. Six further Canadians died in two further crashes during the war. The post-war Jet crashesIn the Black Mountains area of the Beacons in , a de Havilland Vampire jet fighter crashed killing pilot John Raymond Baldock, and then  years later in  a Vulcan bomber crew crashed at Fan Bwlch Chwyth all five crew on board, according to Ystradgynlais History.A friend of a family living near the Vulcan crash site said at the time: “As one can imagine the plane had broken up on impact over a wide area and amongst the debris were the remains of the crew. One eyewitness saw many body parts scattered around and described the scene as horric”. title: crisp hoarders sell packets walkers
story: Crisp hoarders sell packets of Walkers for £ on eBay amid nationwide shortageWalkers crisps are being sold for £ online by opportunist hoarders as shortages of the snacks hit hard for hungry Brits who are faced with empty supermarket shelvesChancers are now trying to sell packets of Walkers crisps for £ online Image: Getty ImagesByTim HanlonNews Reporter:,  Nov Updated:,  Nov | comments Hungry Brits who are unable to get their hands on Walkers crisps due to shortages are now seeing prices of £ being peddled for a packet on eBay.Chancers are seizing on the lack of crisps from the manufacturer to bump up the prices online for people who canapost wait any longer.Crisp hoarders are selling packs of Walkers for around £ as the shortages continue and demand is high, reported the Daily Star. The online sellers are also offering iety boxes of Wotsits and Quavers on eBay for around £ that normally cost around £ from sold-out supermarkets. One eBay trader from Leicester, where Walkers crisps are originally from, is listing a .g pack of Walkers Salt  Vinegar crisps for £. that would usually cost about p.  Another opportunist is trying to sell a g bag of Walkers Salt  Vinegar Squares for £.. It comes as Walkers warned suppliers that their products may not be back on shelves for another month due to an IT problem. A Walkers spokesman said: “We’re doing everything we can to increase production and get people’s favourites back on shelves. “We’re very sorry for the inconvenience caused.” Supermarket shelves have been pictured with few Walkers crisps around the country and they are out of stock on Tesco, Morrisons and Ocado websites. The Walkers crisp shortage has now been going on for several weeks and a spokesman for the Poundstretcher group recently said they had seen deliveries of Walkers products plummet. He said: “They had a change to their systems and the change has taken much longer than expected. “In our last order, instead of getting  pallets – which is equivalent to a truckload – we received seven cases, which is not even a pallet full. It is that bad. “I was in Tesco the other day and the crisps shelves were empty, so I think the bigger supermarkets are being affected more severely as their sales are higher volume.” Crisp aisles are the latest to be hit with shortages, with retail experts also warning people may be hit this Christmas by a lack of trees, toys, booze and food including traditional favourites such as pigs in blankets. news uk-news dad--who-one-uks-"Coronavirus: UK cases increase by a further ,ByLucy Williamson:,  Nov | comments A dad-of-two who was described by doctors as aposone of the sickest Covid patients we’ve ever seenapos has finally gone home after spending nearly a year in hospital.Andrew Watts from Bexley, south London, nearly had his ventilator switched off after he was admitted to Queen Elizabeth Hospital with Covid- pneumonia.The -year-old black cab driver fell ill on Christmas Day  and ended up being one of the longest patient stays the hospital in Woolwich has seen. He spent eight months in intensive care and then two months on a ward which adds up to  days in total, MyLondon reports. After a five-week induced coma and a le-threatening lung collapse, Andrewaposs health deteriorated to such an extent that in February, doctors called his family to tell them they were considering turning his ventilator off. Recalling when he first became unwell, Andrew said: A week before Christmas , I started to feel il. “I wasn’t eating and I was losing weight, but I thought it was just the anxiety getting to me. When I was admitted to hospital with Covid I initially responded well to treatment, but then my oxygen levels started to drop and I was taken for a CT scan. That was when I was told that I had a pneuomothorax, which is a split on the lung.  “I was on my own as this was the height of Covid, with no visitors allowed, so it was a lot to take in. By this point I was crying my eyes out, on the phone to my sister Hannah and my we Hayley, but I didn’t want to tell my mum or my dad. I couldn’t bring myself to tell them.” After overcoming a second lung collapse, fortunately, Andrew’s lungs begun to improve and he was able to come off the ventilator in June . Andrew’s family, including his we Hayley and sons Jack, six, and Joshua, three, were able to visit, although he could only communicate by pointing a stick at letters on a board.  In addition being on a ventilator in ICU for so long meant that Andrew had to learn to talk and walk again. “I kept thinking ‘why me ’,” he said. “It was very hard to stay positive. But I remembered how when I was going through my chemotherapy I was told to look forward, set myself little goals and when I’d achieved them set myself another one. So that’s what I did.” The last two years have been particularly traumatic for Andrew. Read more He was diagnosed with lymph cancer in October  but chemotherapy treatment had been successful and a few months before his Covid diagnosis, he was in remission and on the mend. He spent the majority of  carefully shielding due to his cancer fight. Doctors, nurses, physios and speech and language therapists at the hospital got to know Andrew during his stay.  They all turned out to say goodbye to Andrew on October . Andrew said: “The care has been fantastic but my journey is nowhere near finished yet. Going home is one major goal, but then that just starts another road in my recovery. I started walking just four weeks ago, and my next goal is to walk to my son’s school and back by Christmas.” Comment MORE ON HospitalsCoronavirus" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get our daily coronavirus email newsletter with all the news you need to know direct to your inboxInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: disturbing details behind schoolboy who
story: Disturbing background of schoolboy who murdered and tried to behead pal, Marcel Grzeszcz, who was just  at the time of the murder, stabbed -year-old Roberts Buncis more than  times in a "brutal and prolonged" attack before he tried to decapitated himMarcel Grzeszcz was just  at the time of the murder Image: PAByLorraine King:,  Nov Updated:,  Nov | commentsDisturbing details have been revealed about a schoolboy who murdered his -year-old friend before trying to decapitate him.Marcel Grzeszcz was just  when he stabbed -year-old Roberts Buncis more than  times in a brutal and prolonged attack after luting him into woodlands on December  last year.He has been named and pictured for the first time today after he was sentenced for the brutal killing. Lincoln Crown Court heard harrowing details that Grzeszcz stabbed his defenceless victim in the neck, chest and abdomen before he tried to decapitate Roberts in woodlands in the Fishtoft area of Boston, Lincolnshire. Mr Justice Jeremy Baker sentenced Grzeszcz to a minimum term of  years in custody before he is eligible for release and removed reporting restrictions that allowed the young killer to be unmasked. The judgeaposs decision means more details about the teenager killer can be revealed for the first time. Grzeszcz was expelled from primary school at the age of  after threatening a girl with a kne. The killer had taken a blade with him to class and threatened the terried youngster at St Nicholas Primary School in Boston, Lincolnshire, the Sun reports. Grzeszcz was moved to Haven High Academy but was kicked out for selling drugs and sent to a pupil referral unit.  A mum, who used to take Roberts to primary school with her children, told The Sun: “It’s not his first incident with a kne. “When he was at primary school he took one into class to threaten other kids. He threatened a girl with it and was excluded.” Roberts was a pupil at Haven High Academy and was two days from his th birthday when he died in Grzeszczaposs hands. Grzeszcz refused to talk about the circumstances of the murder but the court heard it was a planned and premeditated killing. Brendan Kelly, QC, mitigating for Grzeszcz, told the court it was accepted that at some point he formed an intention to kill Roberts.  But Mr Kelly argued there was some evidence to suggest that was not the entire plan and something went wrong. Mr Kelly said while it was no excuse, the boy was a troubled young man who been through a period of chaos during the whole of  with his parents, and perhaps unwittingly the authorities. The net effect a troubled young man, Mr Kelly explained. Grzeszcz, who lived near to the grassy area where Roberts body was found, was found guilty of murder at a trial earlier this year but could not be named until Mr Justice Baker lted an anonymity order at his sentencing hearing today. Grzeszcz was today given a sentence of detention at Her Majestyaposs Pleasure and must serve a minimum term of  years in custody before he is eligible for release. The defence opposed an application for the boy to be named, telling the court that both his parents were in court, and were concerned about him being identied.  The court heard Robert had suffered wounds consistent with an attempt to remove his head before his body was found. Passing sentence at Lincoln Crown Court, Mr Justice Jeremy Baker, told Grzeszcz, now , that it was an aggravating feature that he had made a substantial effort to remove the deceasedaposs head.Mr Justice Baker told him: I am sure that as the attack progressed, given the number of serious injuries you inflicted on the deceased, there came a point where you decided to kill the deceased, and you did so. He added: There was a signicant degree of planning and premeditation, including luring the deceased to the scene, and taking the kne with you. Mr Justice Baker said the killing was further aggravated by Grzeszczaposs attempts to conceal evidence - with police finding both the murder weapon and other knives hidden around his bedroom. He noted Grzeszcz was also still unwilling to talk about the circumstances of the murder.  Roberts, who was born in Latvia, lived with his father Edgars just a short walk from where he was killed. He was a pupil at the local Haven High Academy and was due to celebrate his th birthday a couple of days after his death. His father watched on from the public gallery as Mary Loram, QC, prosecuting, gave details of their le in the UK. Miss Loram said: Father and son moved to England from Latvia when Roberts was seven. He made friends easily, learned English and initially at least did well at school. He took up sports, judo and football. It is clear his father worked hard. In his previous statement he says aposhe didnapost have much, but they made sure Roberts had what was needed.apos Miss Loram also read out a brief further victim impact statement from Robertsapos father. In the statement Mr Buncis described how do I put into words what happened to Roberts. His death at the hands of another boy, over what, drugs, fighting, girls, it doesnapost make sense. Mr Buncis added: Iaposve lost my destination, my purpose, my le is in the cemetery. Miss Loram said it was the prosecution case that it was a planned and premeditated killing, with no evidence to suggest Roberts was armed as well. For an adult the starting point is  years, as we say the defendant carried a kne to the scene. However it is important to state that given the defendantaposs age the starting point is  years. That is set down by law.  Mr Kelly said a letter from Childrenaposs Services at Lincolnshire County Council also explained their concerns on naming Grzeszcz for his welfare and that of his family. The jury heard Roberts was found on ground off Alcorn Green in Fishtoft, near Boston, two days before his th birthday. Pathologist Prof Guy Rutty, who examined his body, said he had identied  sites of injury across the neck, chest and abdomen, some containing up to  separate injuries. As well as an attempt to decapitate Roberts he said there were also injuries consistent with someone trying to remove the hand or fingers. Prosecutors said the defendant used such force the tip of the kne broke off and was later found embedded in Robertsapos skull. Giving evidence, the teen claimed he had met up with his friend to hand over a stash of drugs for him to sell, but began arguing when he did not receive the £ payment he was expecting.  Following the attack, Grzeszcz ran home and tried to hide the kne and burn the clothes and gloves he was wearing. He later messaged a friend saying things went wrong and this wasnapost supposed to go down like this. Miss Loram said Grzeszcz had previously discussed a plan with Roberts to rob a shop in order to get money to set himself up as a drug dealer. But, she said, Roberts described the proposal as too mad and refused to be involved. She told the court Grzeszcz feared that Roberts would snitch on him. During the three week trial the jury heard the Grzeszcz also had a collection of knives in his bedroom and had been excluded from his primary school for taking a kne into class.  The jury was told by a fellow pupil that the Grzeszcz routinely carried a kne and would take a blade into his secondary school. At the time of the murder the boy had been excluded for drug dealing in the school. He had previously discussed with Roberts a plan to carry out a kne-point robbery of a shop to get money so he could set up as a drug dealer. The robbery never happened after Roberts described the proposal as “too mad” and refused to be involved. But five days before the murder Grzeszcz carried out a street attack on another boy who was punched and kicked on his way to school. Miss Loram said Grzeszcz intended to set up as a cannabis dealer, and apparently feared that Roberts would snitch on him. He messaged another boy saying “Rob’s a liability” which was met with the response “If he snitch, smack time”. Det Chf Insp Richard Myszczyszyn, of Lincolnshire police, said: “This is an utterly tragic case. I would like to pay tribute to the people who loved Roberts, and had to deal with losing him in such brutal and horric circumstances. Their support for our investigation has been unwavering, and their bravery has been an inspiration. Nothing could bring Roberts back, but our commitment was to try to find some semblance of justice for a grieving family and community. The act was utterly senseless and the consequences, devastating. It will be remembered by officers and staff as one of the worst and saddest cases we have ever dealt with. The level of violence, and that it involved children, makes it almost incomprehensible. “Roberts’s future was stolen and that is an injustice that cannot be undone. We hope today’s sentence might at least offer some closure to those affected. “It’s a stark and chilling lesson on the potential devastation of kne crime. title: fed up kids beg go
story: Fed-up kids beg to go home after shambolic racing event and fireworksA mum who took her boys to the event has told of how they begged to go home, after the cars got stuck in the mud and they were left sitting cold and bored in the overcrowded stadiumStockcars desperately try to make their way around the mud at Odsal Top Image: Hannah Louise FacebookByRobert Sutclfe:,  Nov | commentsA racing event and firework display has been labelled a “disaster” by attendees after the cars got stuck in the mud and the fireworks failed to impress. Hannah, a -year-old mum-of-two took her boys to the stock car racing evening, promising them it would be a night to remember. But she has now told of how they begged to go home, after the cars got stuck in the mud and they were left sitting cold and bored in the overcrowded stadium waiting for the entertainment to continue. Hannah, from Brighouse in West Yorks, spent £ on tickets for her, her children and her mum at the event at Odsal Top on Saturday night.She told Yorkshire Live there must have been “around , people there along with a lot of disappointed children”.I had been bigging it up to my sons aged eight and two, telling them how great it was going to be but all they kept asking me was when could they go home,” she said. It was meant to be stock car racing, banger racing, monster trucks and £, of fireworks. The whole thing from start to finish was a disaster and should have been brought to a close a lot sooner than it was. Were you at the event  Email webnews@mirror  It started at .pm and ended at .pm and most of this time we were just sat around cold and bored waiting for the tractors to pull the cars off the track as it was a mud bath. There were four races that lasted a small amount of time due to all the cars getting stuck in the mud then an hour waiting for the tractors to get them all off the track in-between each. The monster truck was cancelled due to health and safety which I can not understand when itaposs a lot bigger than the tractors that are absolutely fine on the track. The children were bored as there was nothing to entertain them at all. Rather than put another two races on the fireworks should have just been done early and the event ended early. Forty-five minutes before the end three-quarters of the people attending had left - thataposs how bad it was. We spoke to a few stewards who all agreed what a shambles it was and that the event should have been ended earlier. We waited until the end as after sitting in the cold for hours of no entertainment we thought we might as well see the fireworks.”  But the family ended up wishing they had gone to a standard bonfire, in which Hannah said the fireworks would have been just as good. We were utterly disappointed with it all and felt it was a complete waste of money, especially for the price we paid,” she said. “Iaposm pretty sure everyone  who attended would agree which clearly showed how many people left early.” Hannah said the “poor stewards” were being abused by attendees unhappy with their experience, which she said was “also unfair”.And another man wrote on Startrax Stockcar Racingaposs Facebook page: Last night was horric, badly organised, half of the event didn’t even happen, no monster truck as advertised, the apos£, firework spectacularapos was far from it, staff were rude and swearing in front of kids, yet to see a race take place.The commentator did his best to build excitement at what can only be considered a disaster but the odds were against him. Waste of time and money. And a woman wrote: My family go often to watch the racing here and itaposs been amazing! Tonight was appalling. Total embarrassment to the sport. Poor kids are gutted. No monster trucks and not much racing. I feel sorry for the drivers too. The staff stewards attitude was beyond ignorant and rude. Nowhere to stand, the younger kids couldnapost see. A refund is definitely needed! Startrax Stockcar racing manager Steve issued an apology on the eventaposs Facebook page saying the company apologised “unreservedly”. Let us assure you, we have been involved in motorsports and Odsal for  years and indeed promoted at Odsal until its closure in ,” he said. We also invested heavily in itsfor . It has put on this far  successful events in  including the World Stock Car Final only last month.We do care passionately about what we do and, trust us, we are devastated and apologise for the weather and we had invested heavily to put on a great show.It was deemed Health  Safety-wise unsafe for the Monster Trucks to participate, which we announced but as advertised only a part of the show. I make no excuses, it was with the weather not a pleasant night for your family or ourselves and we apologise to your family and friends. In a second post on its Facebook page he wrote the evening will haunt me as a bad memory into retirement, and he firmly denied that his company was out to make a fast buck saying its reputation was extremely important to them. Anyone wanting a refund should contact the company directly. title: girl makes miracle recovery after
story: Girl makes miracle recovery after only eating chicken nuggets for a decadeJessica Thompson would only eat chicken nuggets and her mum, Julia, was at her wits end so hired a hypnotherapist - and now the young girl loves to eat healthy foodJessica has had a miracle recovery Image: WILLIAM LAILEY   MERCURY PRESSByJohn BettAudience Writer:,  Nov | commentsA young girl who lived off chicken nuggets for over a decade now loves to eat fruit and veg - thanks to hypnotherapy. Jessica Thompson, , had an intense food phobia and would suffer anxiety and panic when presented with most foods, but she was ok with beige items and lived mostly on processed chicken nuggets. Her mum, Julia Cain, , was so concerned she sought out professional help and soon the young girl was diagnosed with avoidant restrictive food intake disorder. At her witsapos end, Julia booked a hypnotherapist to help Jessica, and the treatment was so effective that the youngster now loves eating fruit and veg.  What do you think about Jessicaaposs miracle transformation  Let us know in the comments... Julia, from Swindon, Wiltshire, said: She was eating all her baby food and she was trying lots of new food. Then it just stopped, and she would only eat chicken nuggets. Sheaposd have about three or four with fries as a meal but usually didnapost finish it. People would always say, aposshe will grow out of itapos, or apos you donapost give in sheaposll get hungry and eat what you give herapos. The problem is, Jessica would literally rather starve than eat some foods. Sometimes she would crawl into a ball to get away from the food. We knew she was more than fussy but we never thought she would spend a decade of her le eating chicken nuggets.  Jessica was branded as aposfussyapos by doctors over the years, and over the years stuck to beige foods like nuggets, plain bread, and fries. Julia continued: They would all say sheaposs just being fussy, or sheaposs having tummy troubles. As a parent, all you want is for your child to eat. People really donapost understand that it is an illness, not just fussiness. Julia eventually contacted hypnotherapist David Kilmurry, who diagnosed her with ARFID.  For more of the news you care about, straight to your inbox, sign up for one of our daily newsletters here. After just three weeks with him, listening to relaxation MPs before meals, and using an achievement chart, Jessica can now enjoy a roast with her family. He said: Julia contacted me worried and concerned about the limited foods that her daughter Jessica was restricted to, just chicken nuggets and very little . Chicken nuggets are not a whole food group and Jessica came to me extremely unwell, lethargic and anxious. Trying to get Jessica or any person with ARFID to consume is like trying to get an arachnophobe to hold a spider. It sends panic through a persons body retching, gagging and vomiting - just at the thought of an unsafe or new food. For relieved mum Julia, Jessicaaposs achievement means for the first time in  years the whole family can sit down together and enjoy a meal. Julia said: Itaposs nothing short of a miracle that Jessica can eat a full plate of food now. We hadnapost eaten a meal together as a family for years, and now we can. Sheaposs tried  new foods, and even though she hasnapost liked all of them, this is a massive step forward for her. Do you have a story to share  Weaposd love to hear all about it. title: holidaymaker says seaside hotel worst
story: Holidaymaker says seaside hotel is worst in UK with ghastly stains on his bedA horried hotel customer couldnt believe the room he booked at the Royal Albion Hotel in Brighton, and says they offered him a discount - but onlyhe booked to stay with them again.A holidaymaker has said blood and urine stains were found in his bed in a Brighton hotel Image: Kennedy News and MediaByKate BuckNews Reporter:,  Nov | commentsA holidaymaker who booked at the UKaposs worst seaside hotel was horried after claiming to find blood and urine stains in his bed - and says the manager offered him a discounthe booked to stay again. Paul Deery spent three nights at the Royal Albion Hotel in Brighton last month, but claims his horrendousapos room had an unmade bed, tobacco left on the table and pubic hair left in the bath. The -year-old had book to stay with his friend, Paul Mallon, , and paid £ for their stay. But they say the manager of the three star hotel only offered a % refund for their stay. Have you stayed at the hotel  Let us know about your visit, email webnews@mirror  When he doubled down, Paul was given a final offer of a % discount on his next visit to the hotel - which Paul deemed aposcheekyapos as he wanted a full refund and didnapost want to negotiate, norto the venue. Both Paul and Paul were so disgusted by their stay they felt compelled to take COVID tests - which came back negative. Which  magazine slammed the hotel as one of the worst hotels weaposve ever inspected in  and relisted it as such in , condemning the venue with . out of  stars for cleanliness and the same on food. Their brutal review told holidaymakers to avoid at all costs and said the regency-style hotel makes Fawlty Towers look like the Ritz. Paul, a recruitment business boss, said: It was on the seafront, it was like £ for three nights, so it wasnapost cheap. So we get to the room and itaposs cold and damp. My friendaposs bed wasnapost made so it was pretty obvious that it hadnapost been cleaned beforehand. Thataposd be bad enough, but during Covid times, itaposs unacceptable. Especially when on their website, they guarantee all rooms are following Covid regulations and have regular housekeeping. There was blood and urine stains on my friendaposs mattress. My friend actually hadnapost noticed the stains at first, because they were underneath the top sheet. The sheet came up a bit and thataposs when we saw it. There was what I can only gather to be pubic hair in the bath. There were tobacco remains on the table. The whole thing was horric really.  Me and my friend went down to see the manager, but he wasnapost available. We left a message and were told that somebody would be in touch with us, but it didnapost happen. Because we were there for a mini-break, I didnapost want to spend all my time that weekend trying to chase down the manager. We had no other alternatives, everywhere  we checked was booked up so we had no choice but to stay there. We would have moved, but there were no other hotels available. Plus we couldnapost get a hold of the manager so we were in a bit of a stalemate. They said there was daily housekeeping, but our room wasnapost cleaned once. Me and my friend took Covid tests after our stay, just in case. Tests came back fine, thankfully. Paul took the issue further and emailed the hotelaposs manager, hoping to get a full refund. Paul said: When I emailed the manager, he came back saying aposThis isnapost part of our usual high standard, weaposll make sure this never happens againapos, and offered us a % refund, which would have worked out at about £. I was a bit insulted by that, and I emailed back saying aposThataposs not good enoughapos. Then he came back with an email titled aposFinal offerapos, which I thought was a bit cheeky, aswe were in some sort of negotiation. He once again offered the same % refund, and % offwe were to stay again. I sent an email back saying aposI wonapost be staying at the hotel again, so the % doesnapost apply. I want a full refund.apos I didnapost hear from him after that.  Itaposs a bit insulting that weaposre just being ignored. The whole experience was horrible. Iaposm into complaining normally, but this was just horrendous. It wasnapost something silly like a crack in the window, this was blood and urine stains. We didnapost spend too much time in the hotel over the weekend for obvious reasons. Itaposs completely unacceptable, especially for the price I paid. The Britannia website boasts that the -room Royal Albion is aposone of the most popularapos in Brighton and claims it aposoffers character and style in a premier positionapos while being aposproud of its reputation as a family hotelapos. Britannia Hotels have been contacted for comment. After being contacted for comment, the Royal Albion confirmed that the matter had been apossettledapos and Paul would be receiving a refund. title: lady louise could replace prince
story: Lady Louise could replace Prince Harry in important role within Royal FamilyLady Louise Windsor turned  and now can choose whether to become a senior member of the Royal Family. If she decides to do so, she might replace the void left by Prince Harry, Meghan Markle and Prince AndrewLady Louise Windsor has turned  and can decide whether to become a working royal Image: BBC   Oxford FilmsByBethan EdwardsChiara Fiorillo:,  Nov | commentsLady Louise Windsor could replace a void left by Prince Harry when he stepped down as a senior member of the Royal Family.The Queenaposs granddaughter turned  yesterday and now has the option to choose whether to become a working royal. Her parents, Prince Edward and Sophie Wessex, previously said they would allow their children to decide whether to become senior royals at the age of . Lady Louise has not confirmed yet whether she would like to become a senior royal or not, but an insider said the teenager is likely to continue her studies and go to university, the Daily Star reports.What are your views on this story  Let us know in the comments below If she decides to become a senior member of the Royal Family and take on royal duties, Lady Louise may fill a gap left by Prince Harry, Meghan Markle as well as Prince Andrew.The Duke and Duchess of Sussex announced they would step down as senior royals in January , and after that they moved to the US, where they now live with their two children, Archie and Lilibet. Before that, the Duke of York had announced he would step back from royal duties for the foreseeable future because of the Jeffrey Epstein scandal. When Harry, Meghan and Andrew stepped down as senior royals, other members of the Firm had to step up and take on extra duties.  Lady Louise and her brother last year helped her parents with a beach clean. She has more recently followed in the Duke of Edinburghaposs footsteps by taking on the reigns in his carriage driving.During an interview last year, her mum Sophie said Louise and her brother James, Viscount Severn have HRH titles, but it is highly unlikely they will decide to start using them as they will prefer to stay as private as possible.The Countess of Wessex said: We try to bring them up with the understanding they are very likely to have to work for a living. Hence we made the decision not to use HRH titles. They have them and can decide to use them from , but I think it’s highly unlikely. Last month, Lady Louise made her public speaking debut in a BBC documentary to pay tribute to Prince Philip.In the film, Lady Louise spoke fondly of her grandfather, saying: The Duke of Edinburgh has been so involved in my driving which has been so lovely but slightly scary because he invented the sport pretty much. Itaposs incredible to have learned first hand from him and definitely made us closer, I think. She continued: After a competition, he would always ask how it went. His eyes would light up because he just gets so excited when he talks about it. When we would go carriage driving, first of all, he would take me on a dferent route every day, I do not know how he managed to do that, but tell me all sorts of anecdotes about absolutely anything and everything. Heaposs honestly one of the most interesting people, Iaposve ever met. Discussing the Duke of Edinburgh awards, that her grandfather pioneered, Lady Louise added: aposIaposd always wanted to do it because of the skills you develop as a result. My favourite part was my expeditions, just having that level of independence and self-sufficiency and having that sense of achievement when it was finished. news uk-news lady-louise-windsor-royals-new-"Lady Louise Windsor shares memories of Prince PhilipByJenner NewtonRoyal Features Writer:,  Nov Updated:,  Nov | commentsSheaposs the royal who grew up away from the spotlight but is often referred to as the Queenaposs favourite grandchild.But as she turns  today and recently made her public speaking debut, Lady Louise Windsor has now been dubbed as the royal familyaposs secret weapon. Louise is the daughter of Prince Edward and Sophie Wessex and the youngest granddaughter of the Queen and the late Prince Philip.She is currently studying for her A-levels with her mum keen for her to go on to university. But some royal experts believe she could play a key role in the Firm going forward and won over many royal fans with her moving words about her late grandfather earlier this year.  Here we look at how she is becoming, as one royal expert put it, precisely the kind of person the Queen can rely on. Growing up Louise, who officially becomes an adult today and is th in line to the throne, was born prematurely in November . She was born after mum Sophie suffered a placental abruption and was rushed to hospital. Her dad Edward was not present at her birth as she arrived early when he was on an official visit to Mauritius. Love the royals for the Mirroraposs daily newsletter to get all the latest news on the Queen, Charles, Kate, Wills, Meghan, Harry and the rest of The Firm. Click here to sign up. The family live in Bagshot Park, just a few miles from Windsor Castle, and Louise was joined by a younger brother, James, Viscount Severn in .Her first major royal appearance came aged seven when she was a bridesmaid at the wedding of her older cousin Prince William to the Duchess of Cambridge in .She also accompanied her parents on a tour of South Africa in  but public appearances as a child were few and far between. aposFavourite grandchildaposEven though she largely grew up out of the spotlight, Louise has a very close relationship with the Queen and the late Prince Philip. She and her brother James are said to have spent a lot of time with their grandparents due to living close to Windsor and being around at a time when Her Majesty and the Duke of Edinburgh had largely stopped travelling internationally. In fact, growing up, Louise had no concept that her grandmother and the Queen were the same person.Mum Sophie once said: I mean Louise had no concept really that the Queen and her grandmother were one and the same person. “It wasn’t until she was at school that other children were mentioning it and saying, ‘Your gran is the Queen’.Sources have said the Queen and Philip were particularly fond of Louise due to their shared love for the outdoors. An insider previously told the Sun: The Queen loves the fact that Louise and James relish their time at Balmoral, and she has become particularly close to Louise, who seems to have become her favourite grandchild, closely followed by James. Meanwhile, Louise also took up her late grandfatheraposs favourite sport of carriage driving, and recently spoke about they bonded over their love of the hobby. Speaking on the documentary Prince Philip: The Family Remembers, she said: The Duke of Edinburgh has been so involved in my driving, but itaposs slightly scary as he invented the sport pretty much. But itaposs incredible to have learned first-hand from him and it definitely made us closer I think. Family fans But it isnapost just the Queen that Louise has endeared herself to - other royals were also said to be impressed by her during their get-togethers at Balmoral.She is said to have helped out Kate and William by looking after their children while at the Highland estate, and even sat patiently with Princess Charlotte - helping her to draw pictures of the wildle.A source previously told the Sun: Because of her obvious artistic skill, the Queen allowed Louise to look through some of the collection of Queen Victoria’s Highlands sketches which are kept at Balmoral but are rarely dug out these days.Public debut  Now, itaposs not just her family who think highly of the -year-old - Louise won over new fans during her public speaking debut in September.In the documentary Prince Philip: The Family Remembers, Louise spoke fondly and movingly about her late grandfather.Sharing her experiences of taking part in the Duke of Edinburghaposs Award scheme, she said: Iaposd always wanted to do it because of the skills that you develop as a result. But there was certainly an element of making my grandfather proud and honouring him by taking part in the award that has been so much of his leaposs work. And I definitely hope that I have made him proud. Viewers were touched by Louiseaposs comments and one took to Twitter writing: I thought the star of this programme was easily Lady Louise. What a lovely girl she is.Another said: Wow how good was it to see Lady Louise Windsor in her first documentary. While another added: Lady Louise has such fabulous memories of her grandfather, it was a beautul interview and they must miss him very much. Title and royal work Now sheaposs turned , Louise will now have a big decision to make - and it regards her title. When she and her younger brother James were born, their parents decided against them using their HRH titles. However, mum Sophie revealed in an interview last year they do indeed have the titles, and it will be up to them when they turn they want to use them.Speaking to the Sunday Times, Sophie said: We try to bring them up with the understanding they are very likely to have to work for a living.“Hence we made the decision not to use HRH titles. They have them and can decide to use them from , but I think it’s highly unlikely.”  But despite Sophie saying itaposs unlikely Louise will use her title, some experts believe she could be an asset to the royals.Expert Phil Dampier told theLouise could be a secret weapon adding: She seems to be very mature for her age and she’s shaping up to be precisely the kind of person the Queen can rely on in the future. Could there be a role for her in a slimmed-down monarchy  The Queen and Philip had , patronages between them.“You have to ask yourself who is going to continue their legacy with Harry and Meghan and Prince Andrew off the scene  There’s a huge workload there.”While another expert, Richard Fitzwilliam, previously told the Express : Lady Louise has kept a rather charming but low profile.With the number of working royals now fewer and most being from the older generation until George, Charlotte and Louis are able to take on royal duties, there may well be charitable ventures she may wish to support in future years and from that may follow occasional royal engagements. Immediate future  However, now sheaposs turned , itaposs unlikely that Louiseaposs role in the royal family will change quickly.She currently attends a private school in Ascot, where she is studying for her A-levels. And it seems her mum is hoping she will attend university, saying: I wouldn’t force her, butshe wants to. She’s quite clever.She also told BBC Radio : I would hope that she can go on with her studies, which I think she probably will want to do, and I hope that she and her friends will protect her from anything that somebody might want to do.But I have to let her live her le. Itaposs not mine to live. I can only equip her the best that I can, and then she has to make her own choices. “But I hope for the next few years, at least, she will still be able to be as private as she wants to be.And in the same interview, Sophie also revealed how Louise has shunned social media and added: I wouldnapost deny her going onto it. But sheaposs not really that interested in it.“There are a few s that she talks to her friends on. But thataposs basically it. She doesnapost put anything out about herself at all. Sheaposs very private. Sheaposs got her eyes fairly wide open. news uk-news man-lives-hermit--years-"Ken Smith lives as a hermit and finds sustenance in natureByKate BuckNews Reporter:,  Nov | commentsA man has lived as a hermit in the Scottish Highlands for almost  years after he was beaten by a gang of thugs, choosing to spend his days in a log cabin without access to electricity or running water. Ken Smith, , has shunned traditional le since he was  after being attacked on a night out and left unconscious for  days with a brain haemorrhage. Doctors told him he would never be able to speak or walk again, but wanting to prove them wrong and having struck up an interest in wilderness living, Ken travelled to Canada.  While there he says he wondered what what happenhe just exited off the highway and went into nowhere, so he decided to find out - walking , miles on his own before ing home to Derbyshire. But when he got back his world was turned upside down after finding out both his parents had died while he was away. In his grief Ken walked theof Britain before reaching Rannoch in the Highlands.He told a BBC documentary: I cried all the way while walking. I thought where is the most isolated place in Britain I went around and followed every bay and every Ben where there wasnapost a house built.  Hundreds and hundreds of miles of nothingness. I looked across the loch and saw this woodland. In that stretch of wilderness- a full two hours walk from the nearest road - Ken knew heaposd found his new home. Ken built his own cabin from scratch after experimenting with dferent designs using sticks, and for the last  years that has been his haven from everyday le.All these years later the building does have a roaring log fire, but no running water or electricity, the BBC reports.  To feed himself Ken forages in the forest and and grows vegetables, but his main source of food comes from the loch after he taught himself to fish. His days are spent quietly living alongside the loch, and for the past two years he has allowed BBC documentary maker Lizzie McKenzie to film him at his home. But tragedy struck just days after the documentary director Lizzie left Ken, as he suffered a stroke while in the snow in February . He was able to call for help with an GPS personal locator beacon he had been given just prior to the stroke, which in turn sent a signal to Houston, Texas, where operators informed the Coastguard in the UK.  He was rushed to a hospital in Fort William where he spent seven weeks recovering, but despite doctors insistence he shouldto civilisation, Ken refused, just wanting toto his home. A year after his stroke, Ken was injured again after a log pile fell on him and had to once again be airlted to hospital. But in the months after his stroke Ken has been more open to receiving help, and the head stalker of the estate Ken lives on will bring him food every few weeks, paid for out of Kenaposs pension. Aware he is not getting any younger, Ken admits he is no worried about future, and wants to spend his final days at the cabin. news uk-news meghan-harry-stuck-sidelines-royals-"Meghan and Harry’s ‘net-zero’ pledge discussed by expertByJames LeeMonica CharsleyNews Reporter:,  Nov Updated:,  Nov | commentsThe royals have beaten Harry and Meghan at their own game, as the couple failed to make much of an impact raising concerns over the climate crisis, an expert has claimed. Camilla Tomineysaid that the couple were aposstuck on the sidelinesapos and other royals had beaten the Susssexes at their own game. She made the remarks on aposRoyal Insightapos after the Sussexes spoke about the environment in recent days.While the pair voiced their concerns, senior members of the royal family actively participated in Glasgowaposs COP summit, reports the Express.Because of the distance, the Duke and Duchess are struggling to remain relevant, sparking an identity crisis, the expert claims. Describing the coupleaposs approach, Ms Tominey said: “The Duke and Duchess of Sussex are in self-promotional mode which puts them in a problematic situation when it comes to being relevant during Cop.” In a video discussing the situation, Ms Tominey said that the Sussexes’ are “growing their bank balance” which she claims makes it problematic as they try to bolster their image as “global change leaders.Speaking of how other royals are outshining the Sussexes’, the Daily aposs Associate Editor said: “The Royal Family have some good history when it comes to speaking out on the environment, they have a legacy, starting with the Duke of Edinburgh, and the Prince of Wales who covered environmental matters before they were fashionable.”  She also praised Prince William in his role in the Earthshot Prize. She claimed it made the royals more credible than some politicians who attended the summit and aposfailed to make an impactaposapos. Ms Tominey said politicians were in it for the election impact, yet it was less easy to criticise royals who have been campaigning on the matter for decades. She then claimed senior royals have stolen the limelight from Harry and Meghan, as their role is on the “sidelines” of the summit has had little impact. Ms Tominey went on to say the Duke of Edinburgh was the “original green eco-warrior. Prince Philipaposs pioneering approach to the environment is why the Queen referenced him in her video speech, she said. The analyst was also quick in pointing out the absence of the Sussexes’ at the event. Although the Queen still refers to Harry and Meghan as important members of the family, the expert added: “Sheaposs always insisted that Harry and Meghan remain much-loved members of the family - but when you come down to business and the business of royalty, actually theyaposre now outside the tent.” Comment MORE ON Prince Charles, Prince of WalesMeghan MarkleThe QueenPrince WilliamRoyal Family" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get our daily royal round-up direct to your inboxInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: ms praised customers adding hidden
story: MS praised by customers for adding hidden detail on employee name badgesMarks  Spencer shared a post from employee David Parke, , a food PR manager from Croydon, south London, in which he shared a photo of his own badgeAn employee - David - with an MS badge showing dferent pronouns Image: PAByRachel Pugh:,  Nov | commentsMS has been praised for adding a aposhidden detailapos to its employee badges. After a suggestion from an employee, MS workers have the option of wearing “whichever combination of pronouns” they choose. A post on employment  LinkedIn by the retailer said: “Recently, we introduced pronoun name badges for our colleagues, encouraging as many of them as possible to wear whichever combination of pronouns is right for them. “An amazing initiative provided by one of our colleagues Morgen Kane to our Suggest to Steve programme, as we continue to build an inclusive future, together.”MS shared a post from employee David Parke, , a food PR manager from Croydon, in which he shared his own pronoun badge which read: “He Him His” the MEN reports. Mr Parke said: “Giving people the option to display their pronouns at work is really important as it encourages them to show allyship towards trans and non-binary colleagues. “Many of us already include our pronouns in our email signatures, but when you’re talking to people in person it’s useful to know how they want to be referred to in order to help everyone feel comfortable and avoid any misgendering. “Right now trans people in the UK are facing more abuse and discrimination than ever before, and so it’s up to all of us to create an inclusive culture and make sure everyone gets the respect they deserve. “It’s great that MS is proactively taking these sorts of steps to support and celebrate LGBTQ+ colleagues.” Sasha Misra, associate director of communications and campaigns at Stonewall, said: “It’s great to see an increasing number of businesses offering the option of badges with pronouns for staff. “Creating an inclusive workplace starts with everyday actions, and having pronouns on badges is a simple yet impactful way to make sure LGBTQ+ identities are respected – for employees and customers alike.” Comment MORE ON Marks  Spencer" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get email updates with the days biggest storiesInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: mums agonising wait tiny twins
story: Mums agonising wait for tiny twins born at just  weeks to undergo surgeryMum Linzie Mathieson, from Scotland, has opened up about nursing her twin boys to health after they were born weighing just g and gLinzie Mathieson with partner Paul Forrest and their twin sonsByKaitlin EastonReporterLeonie Chao-Fong:,  Nov | commentsA mum feared she would lose her twin boys after she gave birth at  weeks and they weighed just g and g. Linzie Mathieson, from Kingswells in Aberdeen, was rushed to hospital when her waters broke at  weeks and she was put on antibiotics to prevent infection before being sent home to rest.When she went into labour in August this year she was warned her sons Alfie and Harry were unlikely to survive after they were delivered by emergency C-section, the Daily Record reports. She said the boys were delivered and whisked away to the Neonatal Intensive Care Unit where they were worked on for a few hours to stabilise them. Both were placed on ventilators and Harry was given Nitric. At this point, Linzie was told that the next  hours would be critical. Poor Harryaposs lungs were underdeveloped and he needed a lot of help in the first few weeks of his le. Alfie came off the ventilator before his brother but had to be put back on a week later as the pair fought hard and battled every hurdle in their way. The boys have since spent eight weeks in intensive care and four weeks in high dependency after their birth.  They are now receiving treatment on a specialist care ward but due to improvements Linzie hopes to welcome them home soon. She said: “They are both still on oxygen and both have surgery this coming week. They have both done so well and have piled on weight and are taking bottle feeds. The word aposhomeapos has been mentioned this last week so we are hoping to be home in the next few weeksall goes well. “It’s very hard to describe our time in the unit - the first week was a blur - it’s like nothing we have ever experienced. The intensive care unit is very intense but the staff really go above and beyond. They have made our experience and journey so much more bearable. She said: “They are both still on oxygen and both have surgery this coming week. They have both done so well and have piled on weight and are taking bottle feeds. The word aposhomeapos has been mentioned this last week so we are hoping to be home in the next few weeksall goes well. “It’s very hard to describe our time in the unit - the first week was a blur - it’s like nothing we have ever experienced. The intensive care unit is very intense but the staff really go above and beyond. They have made our experience and journey so much more bearable. title: o2 venue slammed charging eye
story: O venue slammed for charging eye-watering £. for ml bottle of waterA fed up gig-goer was flabbergasted by the sky-high drinks prices at the O arena in London – and hes not the only disgruntled punterGobsmacked gig-goer Erik asked: Anyone able to show me a more expensive sugar fix  Image: Deadline NewsByRuaraidh GilmourLaurie Churchman:,  Nov Updated:,  Nov | commentsA live music fan was gobsmacked to see a London venue charging £. for a bottle of water. Erik Van Bommel couldnapost believe the eye-watering prices for soft drinks at the O Arena in Greenwich, south-east London, on Saturday. The peeved punter was visiting the venue to watch synth-pop band New Order when he took photos of the steep drinks prices. Images show the venue charging customers £. for a bottle of Buxton Still Water. The ,-seater stadium also charged £. for a ml bottle of Coca-Cola – which goes for £. at Tesco. Other ml soft drinks, including Fanta and Sprite, set fans back £., while a can of Monster energy drink was priced at £..   According to the menu, punters will need to fork out £. for a g bag of crisps - three times more than the same size bag at Tesco, which costs p.Alarmed by the drinks prices, Erik took to Facebook on Saturday night, writing: Anyone able to show me a more expensive sugar fix His post received more than  likes and  comments from shocked social media users. One user, Gio R Gi, said: Water is what price  What  And people are complaining about the price of petrol  Do me a favour, alcohol is cheaper than all of them. So is not going to the O, thataposs the easiest decision Iaposve made to date.  Peter Smith said: Only times I have been to the O has been to put stuff up or pull it down, and there ainapost no reason for the soft drinks and crisps to be that expensive anywhere under that plastic dome. There is a minimarket just  yards from the door when I was about, people have to pass it going to the car park or trains and buses. Matthew Pateman commented: Iaposd be wanting Salt Bae to turn up and do something for that kind of price. Joel Alderman said: Yeah, I went to the O for Little Mix just before Covid and I saw the price of beer and stayed sober for the evening. The O Arena, now operating at full capacity after Covid- restrictions were lted this summer, is hosting a series of throwback events. JLS, Steps and McFly are set to all take stage in the indoor arena at the end of the month. The O arena has been contacted for comment.Most ReadDont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterComment MORE ON FantaOTescoThe Coca-Cola CompanyMatthew PatemanPeter SmithJLSLittle MixMcFlyStepsPetrol pricesthe O Arena" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get email updates with the days biggest storiesInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: pent up frustration came pouring
story: Pent-up frustration came pouring out as Brits entered US following Covid travel banHours early, and on board BA’s flight, there was a chorus of applause as it, and Virgin Atlantic’s jet took to the skies together in a first for two commercial servicesA party atmosphere greeted those arriving in New York from BritainopinionByGraham HiscottHead of Business:,  Nov | commentsA party atmosphere greeted those arriving in New York from Britain yesterday - with the Daily Mirror among the very first passengers to step through the doors.But the colourful balloons and cheers could not disguise the seriousness of what had come before during  long months of separation for so many families.For during that time there have been missed birthdays, Christmas get-togethers, weddings and, sadly, funerals. Hours early, and on board BA’s flight, there was a chorus of applause as it, and Virgin Atlantic’s jet took to the skies together in a first for two commercial services.You could also hear the palpable sigh of relief from the airline bigwigs present that this moment had arrived, and with it their hope will make a fightback from what has driven other competitors to the wall.  It is also important for those businesses that can finally meet others face-to-face. And it is a big day for tourism chiefs in the Big Apple banking on aof the big spending British shoppers. But yesterday was never really about the firms involved, it was about the iniduals on board - and those who have rushed to book flights - counting down the hours, the day the weeks until they can embrace precious loved ones again. Any video call will never, ever, make up for the emotions witnessed at JFK’s arrivals hall yesterday, when  months or more of pent-up sadness, frustration and finally relief came pouring out.
