title: reunited families weep tears joy
story: Reunited families weep tears of joy as first UK flight arrives in US after travel banA British Airways and Virgin Atlantic flight took off simultaneously from dferent runways at Heathrow for the first time since before the pandemicMembers of the Erebara family embrace after being reunited in New York Image: AFP via Getty ImagesByGraham HiscottHead of Business:,  Nov Updated:,  Nov | comments Families wept raw tears of joy yesterday as they were finally reunited after the lting of the Covid ban on Brits flying to the US.Amid emotional scenes, loved ones who had not seen each another for least  months - many far longer - celebrated being back in one another’s arms again.A sobbing Jill Chambers could not let go of her sister Louise Erebara after jetting in on one of two flights that touched down atNew’s York John F. Kennedy Airport. Almost lost for words, she said: “It’s been heart wrenching. It is so overwhelming.” Louise, her make-up running from the tears she was shedding, said: “It’s been  days to the day since we’ve last seen each other. “She’s missed so much.”  Along with Louise, who now lives in Connecticut, was daughter Denaine, , who held aloft a sign saying “We missed you” and son Bowie, five, with his message: “Do I look bigger,  days missed” and surrounded with love hearts. Kushnahar Islam,  and her daughter Nicola Islam, , travelled from Kent to meet sister Aisha Methew, , her husband Vincent Methew and their two kids Adam and Aaron. It was the first time Mrs Islam had met the youngest grandchild, Aaron. Aisha, from New Jersey, said: “It’s been eighteen months but it feels like it has been  years.  “It is so wonderful to be back together. “It feels so surreal that we are finally here. “We are just so happy.” The first British Airways flight - and another by Virgin Atlantic - took off simultaneously from dferent runways at Heathrow Airport in what is believed to be a first. The flights, and a fleet of others that jetted off from the UK to other US destinations, marked what travel bosses are hoping is a milestone in its long journey back to recovery from the Covid crisis.  Yesterday’s change to US entry requirements follows the UK Government’s decision in the summer to lt quarantine restrictions for fully vaccinated US customers when travelling to Britain. In ,  million people travelled between the two countries, along with , tonnes of cargo. The same year saw £.billion spent by Brits travelling to and in the US, and vice versa. While today signalled the lting of the ban, only double vaccinated passengers are being allowed in.  Another of those counting down the days to yesterday was Maria Butter, , who finally meet up with best pal Mario after  years apart. The pair grew up together in their native Columbia, and Maria, who now lives in Manchester, was due to fly to Mario’s wedding in spring , when the pandemic saw the US impose a ban on UK nationals arriving. “Despite being apart for so long, we were so close,” Mrs Butter, a Spanish teacher told the Mirror. “He is like an uncle to my daughter. “Not being at his wedding was so upsetting. “During the pandemic you realised who was important to you.  Christian Marcelia, , said he was “excited and a bit nervous” to fly to New York to visit his girlfriend. He said: “My girlfriend lives over there, so we’ve been sort of long distance for two years. “I’m going there to meet her family for the first time.” They have been a couple for nearly two years, he said, spending most of that time on dferent continents due to pandemic-induced travel restrictions.“  Phil Drummond, , was on one of the last flights to leave the US before the ban came into force in March last year - and was on the first possible flight back to meet his sister Bobbe . During that time his brother-in-law in the US contracted Covid-, and thankfully recovered. “She would have come to us last Christmas but obviously that couldn’t happen,” he said. “It’s just brilliant to finally get to see her again.” Bobbe were there to greet him, along with her six year old son Ben, who was holding a colourful “Welcome Back Uncle Phil” hand written sign he had made and a red big apple balloon.  “It is so, so strange,” she said. “It is surreal. “In some ways it’s like I only saw him yesterday.” The ban on Brits has devastated many airlines, but few more so than British Airways and Virgin Atlantic which relied heavily on the lucrative transatlantic routes. Sean Doyle, BA chief executive, said yesterday: “We have been hibernating for a lot longer than any of us feared when the pandemic started, so it is great to have an important milestone today. “The emotional toll of the pandemic has been huge, but so has the toll on business. “The amount of business done between the two countries is huge. “You need to get in front of people to build relationships and build economic activity.” Travellers to the US still need to conduct costly Covid tests before arrival. Mr Doyle backed calls for the testing to be ditched. “The evidence we have seen in Europe where double vaccinated travellers don’t have to do testing is…no dferent to what we are seeing,” he said. “With the vaccine programmes I would say we shouldn’t have testing for fully vaccinated passengers.” The BA flight was also billed as its greenest ever for long-haul , and the first directly powered by sustainable aviation fuel. With the focus still on the out of the COP climate summit in Glasgow, some % of the jet fuel used came recycled cooking oil. BA is % of its jet fuel to come from less environmentally damaging sources by . news uk-news royals-weigh-themselves-arrive-sandringham-"Royal family leaves Christmas Day service in SandringhamByJenner NewtonRoyal Features Writer:,  Nov Updated:,  Nov | comments A new film about Princess Diana, Spencer, shows the late princess navigating a traditional royal family Christmas at Sandringham in the early s. But it has ided some film fans and royal experts, with some calling the accuracy of some of the scenes into question - even though the director described the film as a fable from a true tragedy rather than a biopic.However, one of the more bizarre scenes in the movie sees Dianaaposs character being weighed on her arrival at Sandringham. But having to stand on the scales both on arrival and departure from Sandringham is apparently something the royals actually do. Royal expert Ingrid Seward once told Grazia the Queen ensures that the guests weigh themselves on a pair of antique scales in a tradition that dates back to Edward VII.Edward wanted to ensure his guests were fed well and any visitors to Sandringham were required to sit on the device and be weighed upon arrival and departure to seethey had put on pounds during their stay. However itaposs unclearitaposs something the royals still do today, oritaposs something to stay in the history books. Love the royals for the Mirroraposs daily newsletter to get all the latest news on the Queen, Charles, Kate, Wills, Meghan, Harry and the rest of The Firm. Click here to sign up.But regardless of whether they monitor it or not, thereaposs a good chance they might put on a bit of weight given the lavish food available for the royals to eat - especially on Christmas Day. Darren McGrady, who used to work in the royal kitchens, has previously said: After church, thataposs when they have a big lunch that includes a salad with shrimp or lobster, and a roasted turkey, and all of your traditional side dishes like parsnips, carrots, Brussels sprouts, and Christmas pudding with brandy butter for dessert. They stick with the same meal year after year. Later they are said to enjoy tea and cake before tucking into a candlelit dinner later that evening.This year, the Queen is said to be “totally committed” to entertaining her loved ones at her Norfolk home this Christmas after missing out last year because of the pandemic. She is currently in the middle of a period of rest and is not set to undertake any public engagements until at least the weekend for the annual Remembrance Sunday service.Last year restrictions meant the Queen and the late Prince Philip had a quiet Christmas alone at Windsor Castle.But after losing her husband of  years in April, it is understood Her Majesty really wants to see everyone together. A Palace insider said: “This year, more than ever, it is incredibly important to Her Majesty to be surrounded by her loved ones. “The Queen is totally committed to hosting everyone as she hopes to make it back to full health in the coming weeks. “Her Majesty is resting under doctors’ orders with the intention of being able to fully enjoy the company of her extended family over the holiday period. “After being forced to cancel a host of engagements, the family get-together will be the perfect tonic.” Comment MORE ON Princess DianaChristmasRoyal Family" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get our daily royal round-up direct to your inboxInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: savvy aldi customer shares how
story: Savvy Aldi customer shares how she made £ shopping trip last three monthsLiane Greenly, from Lincoln, made everything from cottage pie to cardamom biscuits to ensure she and her partner would have a delicious home-cooked meal every night, after her surgeryLiane Greenly says she made a £ Aldi food shop last three monthsByKate Lally:,  Nov | commentsA savvy shopper has revealed how she made a £ Aldi food shop last a staggering three months. Liane Greenly, , decided to get organised while preparing for an upcoming shoulder operation. She wanted to cook and freeze meals in advance, so her partner wouldnapost have to do everything while she was out of action.She spent £ at Aldi - and managed to make everything she bought stretch for three months, the Liverpool Echo reports.Liane, who lives in Lincoln, made everything from cottage pie to cardamom biscuits to ensure she and her partner would have a delicious home-cooked meal every night while she was recovering. She said: “I had an upcoming shoulder reconstruction surgery booked. “With my partner working full-time and doing a science degree on his days off, there was no way he’d manage all that, plus helping me, cooking and cleaning. So I made a list of our favourite meals, a list of the ingredients, and tubs required to house them. Then I bought a chest freezer. Granted I bought one too small - my maths needs work. I then did what partner calls the ‘anti-shopping list’, where I checked off in my cupboards what I already had in.  I batch cooked the main meal element for our evening meal. Any rice, pasta, vegetables and other sides would be bought and cooked as needed. Batch cooking was a necessity to help us both whilst I faced three months of recovery. It turned out the surgery got cancelled and so we are now using the meals. But as and when the surgery is re confirmed I will re-do all this again. Liane says she used the same base ingredients for ious meals, LatestDeals reports. She continued: “For example, spaghetti, lasagne and cottage pie are all similar until the last few ingredients. Some pasta sauces could be made in minutes, so I quickly whipped them up in a lunch break. We froze everything. I even pre-made marinated fajita kits frozen raw, ready to defrost and fry up. Liane says batch cooking is not only cheaper than cooking nightly, but also makes feeding her and her partner much easier and quicker. She added: My current plan is to [do] batch cooking every two or three months and to restock the chest freezer. “Batch cooking has helped us save at least £ a week easily on our food shopping.” Tom Church, co-founder of LatestDeals, said: “I recently had my first child and I found batch cooking to be a saviour when you’re tired and without much time to cook. “It’s amazing how Liane managed to make her £ shop last for so long. Her cooking looks really delicious too.“If you want to do the same, a quick Google search elicits millions of results for batch cooking recipes.“All you need is some freezer space, some plastic tubs, some tasty ingredients and a bit of time on your hands, and you too can be well on your way to batch cooking success, saving you time, money and hassle. Comment MORE ON Aldi" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get email updates with the days biggest storiesInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. news uk-news sickening-footage-shows-rider-kicking-"Hertfordshire: Horse kicked and punched by riderByChiara Fiorillo:,  Nov Updated:,  Nov | commentsA sickening video appearing to show a hunt rider kicking and punching a distressed horse in the street has emerged. Anti-hunting campaign group Hertfordshire Hunt Saboteurs published a clip showing a woman being aggressive towards the animal after it ran into a road. In the footage, she can be seen kicking the horse and then punching the animal before pulling it by the reins into a vehicle. The rider, dressed in cream breeches and a navy jacket, is believed to be part of Cottesmore Hunt, a foxhound pack based in Rutland. The RSPCA - the largest animal welfare charity in the UK - launched an appeal for information after the video was shared on social media at the weekend.  Several people contacted the charity to urge them to investigate the incident.A person tweeted: This is unacceptable!!! That poor horse was hit and kicked. Every day more shocking evidence emerges of the violent cruelty these hunts inflict on innocent animals. Ridiculous that they are allowed to get away with it.One replied: Totally agree with you something seriously need to be done about it no animal should be treated like that. Another person said: As a horsewoman myself, nothing makes me angrier than seeing footage such as this. It is shameful. There is absolutely no excuse for this behaviour.  No matter how frustrated you are, no matteryou’ve had a bad day. Horses are so sensitive. What a way to make them head shy. Following the incident, Cottesmore Hunt reportedly said it did not condone the actions shown in the video under any circumstances.The Hunting Office condemned the actions of the woman, saying she is not a member of the hunting associations. The RSPCA said in a statement: This footage is really upsetting. We will always look into complaints made to us about animal welfare. We would urge anyone with first hand information about this incident to contact us on   . A spokesman from the Hunting Office said: The Hunting Office expects the highest level of animal welfare at all times - both on and off the hunting field - and condemns the actions taken by this inidual, who is not a member of the hunting associations. The Mirror has contacted Cottesmore Hunt for comment. title: toddlers strange symptoms first blamed
story: Toddlers strange symptoms first blamed on virus were from rare terminal cancerLee-Joshua Hodgson, three, from Kirkby, Merseyside, was taken to the GP with "strange symptoms" including a cough and swelling of the groin area - but was later diagnosed with cancer that had spread throughout his bodyLee-Joshua Hodgson, three, went to the doctors in March last year Image: Josh HodgsonByAaliyah RuggRyan FaheyReporter:,  Nov | commentsA three-year-old boy whose strange symptoms were initially thought to be from a viral infection is now battling terminal cancer. Lee-Joshua Hodgson, three, had groin swelling and a cough when his parents took him to a GP in March last year. He was then taken to hospital, but sent home with antibiotics after doctors decided the odd ailments were caused by a virus, Liverpool Echo reports.Some months later dad Josh found a lump on the back of the toddleraposs knee when he fell over. Doctors initially thought it was a cyst and booked the youngster in for scans in December.The family were sent home on Christmas Eve with the belief all would be okay. But a further scan ruptured the familyaposs le when it showed an extremely rare and aggressive form of terminal cancer.  The cancer - which is called a metastatic rhabdomyosarcoma alveolar - is usually found in the bodyaposs soft tissues.On Boxing Day the youngster underwent major surgery to remove a tumour latched on to his spine.The growth stopped him walking and the cancer in his bones had also caused his hip to break. The cancer - which is called a metastatic rhabdomyosarcoma alveolar - had spread across his body and the little one was given between just five to  per cent chance of survival. Dad Josh said: He had  rounds of radiotherapy which he had to be put to sleep for and six-months of the most intense chemotherapy.  He responded well to it and then was put on maintenance therapy but he was complaining of pain in his back and head and for a long time nothing seemed to get done. I believe the surgery he had on Boxing Day opened a gateway for the disease to spread to other parts of his body. The family was given more devastating news in October of this year when they found out that the cancer had spread to his brain, with one lesion being close to the brainstem. Doctors told the family the cancer was terminal and they do not know how long the three-year-old has left to live.  Josh added: They told me it is terminal, but thataposs the NHS opinion. From a parents point of view, we believe we will find something and we are still looking.Whilst he is still here fighting, we will keep fighting for him. Heaposs the strongest kid Iaposve ever met in my le. Since his terrible prognosis, heaposs been much better in himself. We were told he wouldnapost walk again but we got him walking ourselves. This is a soft tissue cancer, it will pop up everywhere and anywhere because the whole body is soft tissue so why werenapost the right decisions made and scanning done sooner  A fundraiser was set up earlier in the year to help the family to fund specialist, private treatment abroad.Bringing in more than £,, the family said they were in talks with doctors in Spain to discuss options. Josh said: The one we were waiting for, we were told will no longer work for him and we are just waiting to hear back about another combination of treatments. Heaposs on a type of chemotherapy now on the NHS and they think he will respond well to it. It wonapost cure him, weaposve been told we will lose him to this disease but hopefully it will shrink it. Thereaposs a trial thataposs not available here yet, we havenapost got the time, but hopefully this treatment will give him long enough until this trial pops up. In a bid to help the family through this awful time, Kirkby residents Franny Briggs and Jay Murray decided to sleep on the streets from Friday evening to Sunday morning armed with portable phone charges and sleeping bags. Franny, who is recognised in the community for helping those in need, said: We originally wanted to raise funds to help baby Lee travel for treatment but now thataposs not possible as his cancer is too far gone. So this money is to make the family more comfortable with the time they have left. Weaposve done all kinds to raise money but this time we wanted to do something dferent so decided to sleep rough. We didnapost leave the town centre at all and relied on donations given to us on the day, we only had our phones to keep an eye on the fundraising. We raised £, which is great. It was was very cold but we battled on and we had lots of food from local shops and businesses, so we shared that with the real homeless that were there. Anyone wishing to donate can still do so online. Josh added: Franny and Jay said the money was to spend on memories, whatever we decided as a family. Itaposs fantastic, unbelievable what they did. They are brilliant in what they do for the community. Iaposve never even met them before and what theyaposve done for us is crazy. We have that many people to thank but we would like to thank everyone for their support. A gang of kids did a car wash aged three and four and raised £ which was touching, itaposs kids helping kids. The whole community is rallying together. Even people in Huyton. As fantastic as it is. money wonapost change the look on my face but hopefully it will do something when something does pop up. title: urban explorer finds huge abandoned
story: Urban explorer finds huge abandoned cannabis factory inside Scottish pubA group that scours derelict buildings around Scotland shared pictures online of the cannabis factory but, despite several requests, they did not reveal the exact locationAn abandoned cannabis factory was found in a Scottish pubBySally HindDeputy Chief ReporterChiara Fiorillo:,  Nov Updated:,  Nov | commentsAn urban explorer has found an abandoned cannabis factory inside a Scottish pub. A group that scours derelict buildings around Scotland shared pictures online of the factory - but they have not revealed the exact location.Images show huge piles of dried-up plant cuttings in the attic, as well as rows of bags of soil, the Daily Record reports.The bar area still has tables laid out with drinks and cutlery, as well as an untouched wedding cake on display. Half-empty bottles of spirits remain on the bar alongside unopened packets of crisps, while boxes of fertiliser are stacked in the back.  The explorer posted images of the “abandoned weed pub” to a social media group with more than , members. They wrote: “When drink runs out, let’s get high.” Despite several requests by social media users to find out where the pictures were taken, the explorer refused to give out the location. Urban exploring has become massive with more and more bloggers posting on YouTube and social media.  But the pastime has prompted debates on the legalities of accessing private property and appeals from emergency services over safety issues.Over summer, an urban explorer digging through a creepy abandoned house in the Scottish Highlands uncovered the mummied remains of a cat in the kitchen.The empty family home was described as being frozen in time by YouTuber Adam Mark Explores , in a clip that sees him take his k subscribers on a tour of the decaying building. Upon entering the house, Adam described the “dark and eerie” atmosphere, as well as a silence which he said put him on edge as he made his way through.  The video showed the rotting house scattered with old books, magazines and newspapers, dated between the s and s. Speaking over the eerie footage, which panned through the dferent rooms of the house, Adam described the thick layer of dust that coated the furniture and the decayed antique dolls. Most of the windows were stained glass which looked amazing with the sun beaming through projecting the colours into the rooms,” Adam said. Scenes from within the house included a dining room table, covered in dirt but miraculously still set with plates and cutlery. title: youre not friend you use
story: "Youre not a friendyou use racist language - Gary Ballance should know that"Ex-England cricketer Gary Ballance said that he called Yorkshire county teammate, Azeem Rafiq, a “P***” – but said it was done “in the spirit of friendly banter”Gary Ballance admitted calling Azeem Rafiq a p*** Image: Getty ImagesopinionByDarren Lewis:,  Nov | commentsMost of us Black or Asian people you know will have one. The “friend” who thinks knowing us insulates them from the charge of racism when they are being just that. Ex-England cricketer Gary Ballance admitted in a statement last week he’d called Yorkshire teammate, Azeem Rafiq, a “P***” – but said it was done “in the spirit of friendly banter” . Ballance has come clean because, in August , Rafiq gave an interview in which he spoke about the racism he experienced at Yorkshire, including an “openly racist” captain and a dressing room in which racist comments were seen as humorous. The club effectively stuck its head in the sand, but an independent report has blown the whole thing wide open. Sponsors have withdrawn their cash, chairman Roger Hutton has resigned and English cricket’s most successful county has been banned from hosting internationals.  But back to Ballance. He claims to be incredulous that calling an Asian person the P-word could cause the kind of hurt and anguish it did to Rafiq. “If I’d believed it, I would have stopped immediately,” said Ballance. “He was my best cricket mate and I cared deeply for him.” Just not enough to stop using this horrendous racist slur against him. It is easy to believe this is a story just about Yorkshire, cricket or even sport. It isn’t. Go into any office, factory, shop floor or football club you like and you’ll find at least one dinosaur convinced that racist abuse can be used as a term of affection. ‘Can a racist term ever be defined as banter ’ trilled the Twitter account of the BBC’s Question Time. Yes, really. It may as well have asked whether slapping your partner is ever justied. Or whether political corruption is ever justiedthe money is for a good cause.  If ever we needed a snapshot of the institutional racism that infects this country to its core, the past week has provided it. Ironically, there is more outrage and anger directed at those who call it out - as Rafiq has found to his cost - than at the issue itself. Yet the fact remains, across any number of industries and sports, iniduals like him iniably find themselves one of the only Black or Asian people in the room at the mercy of the bigots. Across the country you’ll find iniduals pulling the emergency ripcord defence that their workmate, best friend, neighbour, partner, even husband or we is black. Asthat allows them a free pass to use the kind of language or go down the routes that would otherwise see them vilied. The Government does it even now. Prime Minister Boris Johnson surrounds himself with gatekeepers such as Kwasi Kwarteng, Kemi Badenoch and Priti Patel, believing it protects him from stick for describing Burqa-wearing women as looking like letterboxes. Or describing black people as ‘picaninnies’. Question Time is no exception. Presumably pointing to whatever black or Asian members it has on its production team. And no, it is no defence that the offensive question tweeted was one posed by an audience member to spark debate. Rafiq’s forthcoming appearance in front of a parliamentary select committee may well bring the rest of Yorkshire’s house of cards down. But the shock waves are already reverberating way beyond cricket. PS: You’re not someone’s friendyou’re using racist language towards them. news us-news fertility-clinic-mix-up-leads-"Tearful couple devastated after fertility clinic mix upByChiara Fiorillo:,  Nov Updated:,  Nov | comments Two couples gave birth to each othersapos babies after an alleged mix-up at a fertility clinic, according to a lawsuit. Alexander Cardinale, , and his we Daphna, , welcomed a little girl in September  and became immediately suspicious because the baby had a darker skin tone than theirs.Initially, they put their thoughts aside as they trusted the IVF process and started raising the child as they fell in love with her. However, two months after the birth, they decided to carry out at-home DNA tests, making the shocking discovery that the girl was not their biological daughter and they had been raising someone aposs child. The tests also meant that another couple had been raising the Cardinalesapos biological child. Together with the couple who had been affected by the mix-up, the parents decided to swap the girls and start raising their own babies - after missing out on their births and first months of le.  This week, they announced their decision to sue the IVF clinic where the alleged mix-up happened. Mrs Cardinale said her familyaposs heartbreak and confusion canapost be understated, adding she was robbed of the ability to carry my own child.The lawsuit explains that the couple sought help from the Calornia Center for Reproductive Healthand In VitroTech Labs, an embryology lab, in the summer of .In VitroTech Labs allegedly inserted the embryos into the wrong women. The legal document reads: Daphna was surgically implanted - against her will or knowledge - with the sperm and egg of a man and woman who were complete strangers to her. Meanwhile, Daphna and Alexander’s embryo was transferred to that same couple, Couple Two, a few weeks after Daphna’s transfer procedure. Couple Two carried to term and gave birth to a baby girl - Alexander and Daphna’s biological child - and raised her for months before Defendants’ mistakes were uncovered and proven.  The lawsuit adds that when Mrs Cardinale gave birth to a daughter that was not hers, her husband felt like something was wrong. The document explains: He expected to see a fair child, much like their older daughter. Instead, their Birth Daughter came out with much darker skin and jet-black hair. It was so jarring that Alexander actually took several steps away from the birthing table, backing up against the wall. According to the document, some friends and family members also started questioning the couple about the babyaposs appearance. The situation led to disconnect between the couple as Mr Cardinale - a musician - was worried his we was in denial.  He was so upset that he would stay up at night, staring at their newborn child, wonderingshe was truly theirs, the lawsuit adds. The document says: After learning this, Daphna insisted they take the DNA test, expecting that the results would put everyone’s mind at ease. After several rounds of DNA tests, the Cardinales found out the truth and on December ,  contacted the couple who had been raising their biological child. When they met at a lawyeraposs office, their meeting was terribly uncomfortable, the legal document says. On December , the couples met with their children and for the first time they got to see their biological daughters.  The following day, the Cardinales told their older daughter about the mix-up and she was crushed and terried of losing her birth sister, begging her parents not to switch the babies. About two weeks later, the parents officially switched their children, which took an emotional toll on the whole family. The lawsuit states: The horror of this situation cannot be understated. Mrs Cardinale, who works as a therapist, and her singer-songwriter husband have had to seek help for symptoms of anxiety, depression, and PTSD, the legal action explains. Adam B Wolf, a lawyer representing the Cardinales, said the second family also plans to sue the IVF clinic but wants to remain anonymous. In vitro fertilisationis one of several techniques available to help people with fertility problems have a baby.During IVF, an egg is removed from the womanaposs oies and fertilised with sperm in a laboratory, the NHS explains.The fertilised egg, called an embryo, is then ed to the womanaposs womb to grow and develop. It can be carried out using your eggs and your partneraposs sperm, or eggs and sperm from donors. The Mirror has contacted CCRH and In VitroTech Labs for comment. title: travis scott concert woman 23
story: Travis Scott concert: Woman, , died in crush as her brother tried to save herEight people, including a -year-old boy, died in a crush and stampede that occurred during rapper Travis Scotts gig at his Astroworld music festival in Houston, TexasMadison Dubiski, , was at the festival with her yuonger brother Ty Image: FacebookByWilliam WalkerNews Reporter:,  Nov Updated:,  Nov | commentsThe last victim of the eight who were killed in a deadly stampede during a Travis Scott concert has been named and pictured. Tragic Madison Dubiski, , died as her younger brother Ty tried to pull her to safety before she disappeared into the crowd, it was reported. More than a dozen people were rushed to hospital as eight people died in the crush at the Astroworld music festival in Houston, Texas, on Friday night. A -year-old boy was among those killed, and a -year-old was also hurt, officials said. Festivalgoers described the chaos as people surged to the front, with footage showing fans dancing on ambulances trying to reach those hurt.  All of the eight victims have since been identied as their grieving families mourn their loved ones. Madisonaposs name was confirmed by Harris County Judge Lina Hidalgo. Madison attended the University of Mississippi after graduating from Cy-Fair High School, according to a family memberaposs Facebook page that included photographs of her bright smile. She had been a high school cheerleader, the Houston Chronicle reported. Paying tribute Lauren Vogler, a former classmate, told the publication: She was super bright, uplting and just an all-around sweet girl. I cheered with her when we were younger, and she was always so encouraging. She was definitely the le of the party and loved by so many people. She was definitely one of the apostoo glam to give a damn!apos kind of girls. Another victim to be identied was college junior at Southern Illinois University in Carbondale, Jacob Jurinek. He was described by the schoolaposs chancellor, Austin Lane, as a aposcreative, intelligent young man, with a promising career in journalism and advertising.apos He was on the deanaposs list this semester as a journalism major focusing on radio, television and digital media, a school spokeswoman said. The -year-old lived in Naperville, Illinois, about  miles west of Chicago and spent many weekends with his dad after the death of his mum in , the New York Times reported. The remaining six victims have all already been identied following the tragedy. One, Danish Baig, was  and killed after being crushed while trying to save a relative during the stampede at the concert. His death was confirmed by his brother, Basil, who shared a photograph of him via Facebook and branded him a “beautul soul” and commended him for his “courageous act”.The youngest victim has been named as -year-old John Hilgert. The teenager was described as a loveable baseball fanatic who was one of the nicest human beings.His baseball coach Justin Higgs paid tribute on Instagram : RIP John Hilgert. He got the Call up to the Major Leagues by the Almighty! John made an impact on anyone who met him and they always remembered him. I have memories of John I’ll never forget. University of Dayton student Franco Patino has also been confirmed as another of the victims – with the university releasing a statement about the -year-old’s death. -year-old Axel Acosta, a Washington college student, also died and was described by the institution as aposa young man with a vibrant future.apos Meanwhile, People confirmed that -year-old dancer Brianna Rodriguez was another of the eight killed in the tragedy.  Her grieving family are quoted by the outlet stating that Brianna is: “Gone from our sites [sic], but never from our hearts.”And -year-old Rodolfo aposRudyapos Peña was confirmed as another one of the victims by the Laredo Morning Times. Survivors and families of the victims are reportedly set to take legal action following the tragedy. Travis Scott, meanwhile, will cover all funeral costs for victims, his reps said. title: woman left stitches after catching
story: Woman left in stitches after catching handyman slagging off her decor on flat cameraThe video went viral after it was shared on TikTok, where the owner of the flat joked: "Turns out the maintenance guys at my apartment had opinions about my interior design"The video racked up more than . million views Image: kathopejones TikTokByRosaleen FentonAudience Writer:,  Nov | commentsWeaposve all watched enough interior design programmes to know that people can have very dferent styles. From crushed velvet to rainbow walls - what one person may love, another may abhor. But thataposs the great thing about interior design, you can have what you like in your own home, regardless of what others may think.One woman left people in stitches recently after sharing a very awkward moment she caught on camera on TikTok.Kat Hope Jones wasnapost in the flat when two maintenance workers visited - but a camera set up to monitor her dog Hudson captured the moment.One of the workers can be heard exclaiming: Everythingaposs pink, the refrigerator, the washing machine....sheaposs got pink s*** everywhere.  Get the news you want straight to your inbox.for a Mirror newsletter here The other worker replies: Yuck, before they both move away from the camera. The initial video left people in hysterics, as one joked: Theyaposre mad they donapost have taste. But another wrote: They can have their own opinion, not everyone likes the same stuff. Another maintenance worker added: Iaposve worked in the industry for ten years now and my tech tells me to always act like thereaposs a camera inside, evenyou canapost see one.In a follow-up video, Kat said she thought the video was funny - and appealed for commenters to treat the workers with respect. She said: I donapost think itaposs cool to be mean. I think weaposve all been mistreated before in our le and had someone say something that wasnapost kind to us. A third commenter wrote: I love that youaposre not upset like some of your comments, itaposs hilarious. Everyone has dferent tastes, cute house though. Kat replied: It was super silly. Whataposs even funnier is that the girl who lives across the hall from me has a super pink apartment toolt with a crying emoji. title: model claims instagram keep deleting
story: Model claims Instagram keep deleting account as Im so hot people just think Im fakeVeronika Rajek, a former Miss Slovakia  finalist, travels the world making content for her Instagram – and claims people are "always surprised" when they meet her for the first timeVeronika Rajeka says that le is harder for beautul people Image: Jam Press @veronikarajekByDominique Starbuck:,  Nov | commentsA model has claimed her Instagram keeps getting deleted because too many people believe she isnapost a real person. Veronika Rajekaposs social media profile are regularly reported as being fake, she has claimed. The -year-old believes that aposle is harder for beautul people and that she so hot people just think Iaposm fake. Others allegedly bully the former Miss Slovakia  finalist for having had plastic surgery, which she insists isnapost true. People don’t even believe I exist, Veronika said. It’s pretty discriminatory that other women can do the same thing as me and I can’t, and I just get deleted because of my looks.  I call myself an alien as people don’t believe I’m real. They think I’m an AI robot or a catfish online. People say beautul people have it easy but I have it worse as people make it harder for me because I’m beautul.The model, based in Vienna, Austria, travels the world making content for her Instagram – and claims people are always surprised when they meet her for the first time.Veronika claims she receives hundreds of messages from women body shaming her on a regular basis and that many claim she uses filters to advance her looks.  Veronika, who has . million followers on Instagram, said: I get messages from men who donapost think Iaposm real but the worst messages on my Instagram are from women asking me why I’m pretending and asking for proof. I don’t make any adjustments, shaping or filters – I use a skin smoothing tool but I think that’s normal. Skinny girls are body shaming plus-sized models but I’m being body shamed too as they donapost think I’m natural.  I get more abuse from women as they are jealous and they think I want their boyfriend. Only women can hurt other women so strongly. I donapost think I’m perfect but I’m natural in real le, but people are scared of me and donapost want to talk to me. To end the rumours of plastic surgery and claims sheaposs a catfish or robot, Veronika has resorted to desperate measures. She is planning to get a scan of her breasts to prove people wrong. The model paid £ for a breast examination while in Dubai in October, which included a quick scan. She said: I was forced to do this check-up to get people to believe me. People question the naturality of my breasts so I went to a doctor to get a breast examination and proof that they’re real, with no enhancements, objects or scars. My doctor was really surprised as she thought I’d had surgery too and said I had the most beautul natural breasts.  I worked out so much at teenage years that I developed muscles which make my breasts a nice shape. I’m not trying to be sexual, I just have big boobs. God gave me these gts and I want people to believe me. Veronika takes good care of her body - not drinking or partying, instead working out five times a week. But her beauty has also come at a price. She added: ‘I don’t have many friends but I feel good. If you feel beautul the way you are, then you are beautul. If you feel confident in your body and you are plus-sized, then just be confident. “If you have had plastic surgery, just be honest. If you take care of yourself, you can be beautul too. news world-news princess-charlene-s-monaco-following-"Princess Charlene celebrates th wedding anniversaryByJenner NewtonRoyal Features Writer:,  Nov | commentsPrincess Charlene of Monaco has finally ed to the principality after spending most of this year on an extended stay in South Africa away from her husband Prince Albert and their children.The -year-old was seen disembarking a private jet at Nice airport this morning before she boarded a helicopter to fly to the Princeaposs Palace in Monaco.Pictures posted on Instagram later showed Charlene embracing her husband as they posed for photos with their seven-year-old twins Prince Jacques and Princess Gabriella in what was described as a reunion filled with joy and emotion.The caption said: On Monday November  in the early morning, HSH Prince Albert II, accompanied by HSH Princess Stéphanie as well as Hereditary Prince Jacques and Princess Gabriella welcomed HSH Princess Charlene to the Principality of Monaco. A reunion filled with joy and emotion. Charlene travelled to South Africa in March for a conservation trip but her prolonged absence from Monaco had seen her and Albert face calls to revealtheir marriage was on the rocks following rumours all was not well in their relationship.According to the , her trip to South Africa came shortly after reports surfaced that her husband, , was facing a paternity suit after being accused of fathering a love child early in their relationship. He already has two children out of wedlock.  Love the royals for the Mirroraposs daily newsletter to get all the latest news on the Queen, Charles, Kate, Wills, Meghan, Harry and the rest of The Firm. Click here to sign up. Charlene, , failed toto Monaco to celebrate her th anniversary with her husband in July but said she wasnapost allowed to travel due to a serious ear, nose and throat infection and has since had several surgeries. In August, Albert flew out to South Africa with the coupleaposs children and they posted images of themselves enjoying time as a family on social media. But despite the pictures, French media questioned their relationship, with respected Madame Figaro magazine asking: How long will Albert II of Monaco go on bearing this affront, which is becoming ridiculous Later, both Charlene and Albert vehemently denied the rumours about their marriage, with Albert telling PEOPLE in September: She didnapost leave Monaco in a huff! She didnapost leave because she was mad at me or at anybody . She was going down to South Africa to reassess her Foundationaposs work down there and to take a little time off with her brother and some friends.It was only supposed to be a week-long, -day maximum stay, and [she is still there now] because she had this infection all these medical complications arose. She didnapost go into exile. It was absolutely just a medical problem which had to be treated. While Charlene told a South African TV news channel: Albert is my rock and strength and without his love and support I would not have been able to get through this painful time.  Albert and Charlene met in  - the same year Charlene represented South Africa in the Sydney Olympics in swimming. They married in July  but there were reports before they tied the knot that she tried to leave Monaco andto South Africa. The Palace dismissed the claims as ugly rumours.The couple also spent their first days of the marriage apart with the pair staying in separate hotels in the South African city of Durban - due to Albert attending a meeting of the International Olympic Committee.The palace later said they made up for their time apart on a secret honeymoon - thought to have been in Mozambique. Three years later Charlene gave birth to twins Prince Jacques and Princess Gabriella. In the past, she has spoken about missing her native South Africa.She told Eyewitness News : I am African and this is my heritage. It will always be. It’s in my heart and in my veins.I have the privilege of having this le, but I miss my family and my friends in South Africa and Iaposm often sad because I cannot always be there for them. title: egg producers call for flexible pricing as costs rise
story: We are excited to announce a new home for the Evening Express content online, with a bigger and better website in partnership with The Press and Journal. We have spoken to our readers, and our aim is to deliver you everything that you need to know, together in one place.If you are a subscriber or thinking about joining our digital community, find out what it means for you below.In order to give you access to the news that you need, we have expanded our newsrooms and created dedicated news teams to serve you and our extended local communities across Aberdeen, Aberdeenshire, the Highlands and Islands and the North and North-East of Scotland. We will deliver you more content, live news as it happens, as well as breaking crime news and the latest from court, together in one place. We have also found new ways of telling our stories online, from in-depth investigations through to full- documentaries and podcasts.There is no change to The Press and Journal and the Evening Express newspaper or ePapers. The newspapers will continue to be available for purchase at your local store, delivered to your home, or as an ePaper . We will continue to deliver you the best stories in print, that you have come to expect from the PJ and the Evening Express.Our ePapers are a full replica version of the newspaper, published online,  days a week. You can access the PJ and the Evening Express ePaper via our dedicated ePaper apps where you can save and share stories, access all the paper supplements easily via their dedicated menu and even play interactive puzzles!If you would like to find out more about subscribing to the PJ or the Evening Express ePaper, please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team on Your subscription to the Press and Journal will allow you to access all of the Evening Express stories which are now available on the PJ website. All of the best Evening Express content, including columnists and football analysis will now appear on the PJ website and will be available for you as part of your subscription.If you have an ePaper subscription there will be no change as to how you access your Press and Journal ePaper.The new website is now live. Evening Express content can now be found on The Press and Journal website.When you purchased your subscription an email was sent to your account with your login details. To reset your password please use the following link.Please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team, on  Monday # Friday, am # pm, or email.Your subscription will continue as normal and all your existing subscriber benefits will remain in place. There are changes as to how you access your subscription benefits. See below, depending on what type of subscription you have.If you are an existing Evening Express Web subscriber, you can log in to your account as normal through The Press and Journal website.If you have an ePaper subscription you can access your ePaper on The Press and Journal website here.Or via a new link in your Daily ePaper email.There is no change to your reoccurring billing agreement. If you purchase a new subscription through The PJ website the price is subject to change and may be more than your current subscription. If you have any questions about your current subscription or how to access your subscription benefits in the future, please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team, on   Monday # Friday, am # pm, or email.The new website is now live. Evening Express content can now be found on The Press and Journal website.Your subscription will continue as normal and all your existing subscriber benefits will remain in place.You can access your ePaper on The Press and Journal website here.Or via a new link in your Daily ePaper email.If you have any questions about your current subscription or how to access your subscription benefits in the future, please contact our Digital News Subscription Team   , or email.Yes, we will still send you a daily ePaper reminder with a link to the Evening Express ePaper, every time there is a new ePaper available .No, the Evening Express ePaper app will remain exactly the same.If you are an existing Evening Express Web subscriber, you can log in to your account as normal through the PJ website here.If you have an ePaper subscription you can access your ePaper on the PJ website here.Or via a new link in your Daily ePaper email.Yes, your existing Evening Express login details work on The Press and Journal. If you navigate to the Evening Express website or have website links saved, you will be automatically redirected to The Press and Journal website.Yes. You will find all the content that you would have normally found at the Evening Express here.Our combined newsroom will deliver you all of the Evening Express content that you would expect from The Evening Express website, plus more! We will continue to bring you the very best local news, football insight and in-depth features, as well as your favourite Evening Express columnists. These can all be found on The Press and Journal website as well as live news # updated as it happens # breaking crime news and the latest from court. You can also find our very best content that was published originally on the Evening Express website. These articles will be marked as originally appearing on the Evening Express website.Some Evening Express content will be moved to The Press and Journal website. Your bookmarked links will automatically redirect to the corresponding page on The Press and Journal website.Yes, The Press and Journal and the Evening Express social pages will continue. We will curate content specically for our audiences through our Facebook, Twitter and Instagram channels. All articles will link to The PJ website.Your registration details that you set up on the Evening Express website will work on The Press and Journal website. Please log in to your account as normal via the top right hand corner of the website or with this link.If you have forgotten your login or password please click the password reset link and follow the instructions.Yes. All registered users can access  free articlesevery  days. Please note, this information is correct at the time of publication, however, DC Thomson reserve the right to change this in the future.No, you will no longer receive Evening Express branded newsletters. You will now receive Press and Journal newsletters. If you do not wish to receive these, click the #unsubscribe# link at the bottom of the newsletter email.The Press and Journal has a Web subscription available which will give you access to all content on site from The Press and Journal and the Evening Express. You can purchase a PJ Web or PJ ePaper subscription here: www.pressandjournal subscribeThe Evening Express ePaper subscription is still available for purchase here.If you need help deciding what subscription is best for you, our Digital News Subscriptions Team are standing by to help. The Press and Journal Web subscription will give you access to all content on site from The PJ and the Evening Express. You can purchase a Press and Journal Web or Press and Journal ePaper subscription here.If you have an existing Evening Express Web subscription then all your subscription benefits are now available on The Press and Journal site. You have access to a bigger and better website, with all your favourite Evening Express content plus more.If you need help deciding what subscription is best for you, our Digital News Subscriptions Team are standing by to help. Please call on    Monday # Friday, am # pm, or email.You can purchase an Evening Express ePaper subscription here.Yes, you can. story: We are excited to announce a new home for the Evening Express content online, with a bigger and better website in partnership with The Press and Journal. We have spoken to our readers, and our aim is to deliver you everything that you need to know, together in one place.If you are a subscriber or thinking about joining our digital community, find out what it means for you below.In order to give you access to the news that you need, we have expanded our newsrooms and created dedicated news teams to serve you and our extended local communities across Aberdeen, Aberdeenshire, the Highlands and Islands and the North and North-East of Scotland. We will deliver you more content, live news as it happens, as well as breaking crime news and the latest from court, together in one place. We have also found new ways of telling our stories online, from in-depth investigations through to full- documentaries and podcasts.There is no change to The Press and Journal and the Evening Express newspaper or ePapers. The newspapers will continue to be available for purchase at your local store, delivered to your home, or as an ePaper . We will continue to deliver you the best stories in print, that you have come to expect from the PJ and the Evening Express.Our ePapers are a full replica version of the newspaper, published online,  days a week. You can access the PJ and the Evening Express ePaper via our dedicated ePaper apps where you can save and share stories, access all the paper supplements easily via their dedicated menu and even play interactive puzzles!If you would like to find out more about subscribing to the PJ or the Evening Express ePaper, please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team on Your subscription to the Press and Journal will allow you to access all of the Evening Express stories which are now available on the PJ website. All of the best Evening Express content, including columnists and football analysis will now appear on the PJ website and will be available for you as part of your subscription.If you have an ePaper subscription there will be no change as to how you access your Press and Journal ePaper.The new website is now live. title: scotland hub reduce livestock gases
story: We are excited to announce a new home for the Evening Express content online, with a bigger and better website in partnership with The Press and Journal. We have spoken to our readers, and our aim is to deliver you everything that you need to know, together in one place.If you are a subscriber or thinking about joining our digital community, find out what it means for you below.In order to give you access to the news that you need, we have expanded our newsrooms and created dedicated news teams to serve you and our extended local communities across Aberdeen, Aberdeenshire, the Highlands and Islands and the North and North-East of Scotland. We will deliver you more content, live news as it happens, as well as breaking crime news and the latest from court, together in one place. We have also found new ways of telling our stories online, from in-depth investigations through to full- documentaries and podcasts.There is no change to The Press and Journal and the Evening Express newspaper or ePapers. The newspapers will continue to be available for purchase at your local store, delivered to your home, or as an ePaper . We will continue to deliver you the best stories in print, that you have come to expect from the PJ and the Evening Express.Our ePapers are a full replica version of the newspaper, published online,  days a week. You can access the PJ and the Evening Express ePaper via our dedicated ePaper apps where you can save and share stories, access all the paper supplements easily via their dedicated menu and even play interactive puzzles!If you would like to find out more about subscribing to the PJ or the Evening Express ePaper, please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team on Your subscription to the Press and Journal will allow you to access all of the Evening Express stories which are now available on the PJ website. All of the best Evening Express content, including columnists and football analysis will now appear on the PJ website and will be available for you as part of your subscription.If you have an ePaper subscription there will be no change as to how you access your Press and Journal ePaper.The new website is now live. Evening Express content can now be found on The Press and Journal website.When you purchased your subscription an email was sent to your account with your login details. To reset your password please use the following link.Please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team, on  Monday # Friday, am # pm, or email.Your subscription will continue as normal and all your existing subscriber benefits will remain in place. There are changes as to how you access your subscription benefits. See below, depending on what type of subscription you have.If you are an existing Evening Express Web subscriber, you can log in to your account as normal through The Press and Journal website.If you have an ePaper subscription you can access your ePaper on The Press and Journal website here.Or via a new link in your Daily ePaper email.There is no change to your reoccurring billing agreement. If you purchase a new subscription through The PJ website the price is subject to change and may be more than your current subscription. If you have any questions about your current subscription or how to access your subscription benefits in the future, please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team, on   Monday # Friday, am # pm, or email.The new website is now live. If you navigate to the Evening Express website or have website links saved, you will be automatically redirected to The Press and Journal website.Yes. You will find all the content that you would have normally found at the Evening Express here.Our combined newsroom will deliver you all of the Evening Express content that you would expect from The Evening Express website, plus more! We will continue to bring you the very best local news, football insight and in-depth features, as well as your favourite Evening Express columnists. These can all be found on The Press and Journal website as well as live news # updated as it happens # breaking crime news and the latest from court. You can also find our very best content that was published originally on the Evening Express website. These articles will be marked as originally appearing on the Evening Express website.Some Evening Express content will be moved to The Press and Journal website. Your bookmarked links will automatically redirect to the corresponding page on The Press and Journal website.Yes, The Press and Journal and the Evening Express social pages will continue. We will curate content specically for our audiences through our Facebook, Twitter and Instagram channels. All articles will link to The PJ website.Your registration details that you set up on the Evening Express website will work on The Press and Journal website. Please log in to your account as normal via the top right hand corner of the website or with this link.If you have forgotten your login or password please click the password reset link and follow the instructions.Yes. title: new contractor swoops in to save banff harbour from devastation this winter
story: We are excited to announce a new home for the Evening Express content online, with a bigger and better website in partnership with The Press and Journal. We have spoken to our readers, and our aim is to deliver you everything that you need to know, together in one place.If you are a subscriber or thinking about joining our digital community, find out what it means for you below.In order to give you access to the news that you need, we have expanded our newsrooms and created dedicated news teams to serve you and our extended local communities across Aberdeen, Aberdeenshire, the Highlands and Islands and the North and North-East of Scotland. We will deliver you more content, live news as it happens, as well as breaking crime news and the latest from court, together in one place. We have also found new ways of telling our stories online, from in-depth investigations through to full- documentaries and podcasts.There is no change to The Press and Journal and the Evening Express newspaper or ePapers. The newspapers will continue to be available for purchase at your local store, delivered to your home, or as an ePaper . We will continue to deliver you the best stories in print, that you have come to expect from the PJ and the Evening Express.Our ePapers are a full replica version of the newspaper, published online,  days a week. You can access the PJ and the Evening Express ePaper via our dedicated ePaper apps where you can save and share stories, access all the paper supplements easily via their dedicated menu and even play interactive puzzles!If you would like to find out more about subscribing to the PJ or the Evening Express ePaper, please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team on Your subscription to the Press and Journal will allow you to access all of the Evening Express stories which are now available on the PJ website. All of the best Evening Express content, including columnists and football analysis will now appear on the PJ website and will be available for you as part of your subscription.If you have an ePaper subscription there will be no change as to how you access your Press and Journal ePaper.The new website is now live. Evening Express content can now be found on The Press and Journal website.When you purchased your subscription an email was sent to your account with your login details. To reset your password please use the following link.Please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team, on  Monday # Friday, am # pm, or email.Your subscription will continue as normal and all your existing subscriber benefits will remain in place. There are changes as to how you access your subscription benefits. If you purchase a new subscription through The PJ website the price is subject to change and may be more than your current subscription. title: council strikes explained why are workers walking out
story: We are excited to announce a new home for the Evening Express content online, with a bigger and better website in partnership with The Press and Journal. We have spoken to our readers, and our aim is to deliver you everything that you need to know, together in one place.If you are a subscriber or thinking about joining our digital community, find out what it means for you below.In order to give you access to the news that you need, we have expanded our newsrooms and created dedicated news teams to serve you and our extended local communities across Aberdeen, Aberdeenshire, the Highlands and Islands and the North and North-East of Scotland. We will deliver you more content, live news as it happens, as well as breaking crime news and the latest from court, together in one place. We have also found new ways of telling our stories online, from in-depth investigations through to full- documentaries and podcasts.There is no change to The Press and Journal and the Evening Express newspaper or ePapers. The newspapers will continue to be available for purchase at your local store, delivered to your home, or as an ePaper . We will continue to deliver you the best stories in print, that you have come to expect from the PJ and the Evening Express.Our ePapers are a full replica version of the newspaper, published online,  days a week. You can access the PJ and the Evening Express ePaper via our dedicated ePaper apps where you can save and share stories, access all the paper supplements easily via their dedicated menu and even play interactive puzzles!If you would like to find out more about subscribing to the PJ or the Evening Express ePaper, please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team on Your subscription to the Press and Journal will allow you to access all of the Evening Express stories which are now available on the PJ website. All of the best Evening Express content, including columnists and football analysis will now appear on the PJ website and will be available for you as part of your subscription.If you have an ePaper subscription there will be no change as to how you access your Press and Journal ePaper.The new website is now live. Evening Express content can now be found on The Press and Journal website.When you purchased your subscription an email was sent to your account with your login details. To reset your password please use the following link.Please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team, on  Monday # Friday, am # pm, or email.Your subscription will continue as normal and all your existing subscriber benefits will remain in place. There are changes as to how you access your subscription benefits. See below, depending on what type of subscription you have.If you are an existing Evening Express Web subscriber, you can log in to your account as normal through The Press and Journal website.If you have an ePaper subscription you can access your ePaper on The Press and Journal website here.Or via a new link in your Daily ePaper email.There is no change to your reoccurring billing agreement. If you purchase a new subscription through The PJ website the price is subject to change and may be more than your current subscription. If you have any questions about your current subscription or how to access your subscription benefits in the future, please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team, on   Monday # Friday, am # pm, or email.The new website is now live. If you navigate to the Evening Express website or have website links saved, you will be automatically redirected to The Press and Journal website.Yes. You will find all the content that you would have normally found at the Evening Express here.Our combined newsroom will deliver you all of the Evening Express content that you would expect from The Evening Express website, plus more! We will continue to bring you the very best local news, football insight and in-depth features, as well as your favourite Evening Express columnists. These can all be found on The Press and Journal website as well as live news # updated as it happens # breaking crime news and the latest from court. You can also find our very best content that was published originally on the Evening Express website. These articles will be marked as originally appearing on the Evening Express website.Some Evening Express content will be moved to The Press and Journal website. Your bookmarked links will automatically redirect to the corresponding page on The Press and Journal website.Yes, The Press and Journal and the Evening Express social pages will continue. We will curate content specically for our audiences through our Facebook, Twitter and Instagram channels. All articles will link to The PJ website.Your registration details that you set up on the Evening Express website will work on The Press and Journal website. Please log in to your account as normal via the top right hand corner of the website or with this link.If you have forgotten your login or password please click the password reset link and follow the instructions.Yes. All registered users can access  free articlesevery  days. Please note, this information is correct at the time of publication, however, DC Thomson reserve the right to change this in the future.No, you will no longer receive Evening Express branded newsletters. You will now receive Press and Journal newsletters. If you do not wish to receive these, click the #unsubscribe# link at the bottom of the newsletter email.The Press and Journal has a Web subscription available which will give you access to all content on site from The Press and Journal and the Evening Express. You can purchase a Press and Journal Web or Press and Journal ePaper subscription here.If you have an existing Evening Express Web subscription then all your subscription benefits are now available on The Press and Journal site. You have access to a bigger and better website, with all your favourite Evening Express content plus more.If you need help deciding what subscription is best for you, our Digital News Subscriptions Team are standing by to help. title: have your say aberdeen city centre plans
story: We are excited to announce a new home for the Evening Express content online, with a bigger and better website in partnership with The Press and Journal. We have spoken to our readers, and our aim is to deliver you everything that you need to know, together in one place.If you are a subscriber or thinking about joining our digital community, find out what it means for you below.In order to give you access to the news that you need, we have expanded our newsrooms and created dedicated news teams to serve you and our extended local communities across Aberdeen, Aberdeenshire, the Highlands and Islands and the North and North-East of Scotland. We will deliver you more content, live news as it happens, as well as breaking crime news and the latest from court, together in one place. We have also found new ways of telling our stories online, from in-depth investigations through to full- documentaries and podcasts.There is no change to The Press and Journal and the Evening Express newspaper or ePapers. The newspapers will continue to be available for purchase at your local store, delivered to your home, or as an ePaper . We will continue to deliver you the best stories in print, that you have come to expect from the PJ and the Evening Express.Our ePapers are a full replica version of the newspaper, published online,  days a week. You can access the PJ and the Evening Express ePaper via our dedicated ePaper apps where you can save and share stories, access all the paper supplements easily via their dedicated menu and even play interactive puzzles!If you would like to find out more about subscribing to the PJ or the Evening Express ePaper, please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team on Your subscription to the Press and Journal will allow you to access all of the Evening Express stories which are now available on the PJ website. All of the best Evening Express content, including columnists and football analysis will now appear on the PJ website and will be available for you as part of your subscription.If you have an ePaper subscription there will be no change as to how you access your Press and Journal ePaper.The new website is now live. Evening Express content can now be found on The Press and Journal website.When you purchased your subscription an email was sent to your account with your login details. title: ironworks inverness new luxury hotel plans
story: We are excited to announce a new home for the Evening Express content online, with a bigger and better website in partnership with The Press and Journal. We have spoken to our readers, and our aim is to deliver you everything that you need to know, together in one place.If you are a subscriber or thinking about joining our digital community, find out what it means for you below.In order to give you access to the news that you need, we have expanded our newsrooms and created dedicated news teams to serve you and our extended local communities across Aberdeen, Aberdeenshire, the Highlands and Islands and the North and North-East of Scotland. We will deliver you more content, live news as it happens, as well as breaking crime news and the latest from court, together in one place. We have also found new ways of telling our stories online, from in-depth investigations through to full- documentaries and podcasts.There is no change to The Press and Journal and the Evening Express newspaper or ePapers. The newspapers will continue to be available for purchase at your local store, delivered to your home, or as an ePaper . We will continue to deliver you the best stories in print, that you have come to expect from the PJ and the Evening Express.Our ePapers are a full replica version of the newspaper, published online,  days a week. You can access the PJ and the Evening Express ePaper via our dedicated ePaper apps where you can save and share stories, access all the paper supplements easily via their dedicated menu and even play interactive puzzles!If you would like to find out more about subscribing to the PJ or the Evening Express ePaper, please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team on Your subscription to the Press and Journal will allow you to access all of the Evening Express stories which are now available on the PJ website. All of the best Evening Express content, including columnists and football analysis will now appear on the PJ website and will be available for you as part of your subscription.If you have an ePaper subscription there will be no change as to how you access your Press and Journal ePaper.The new website is now live. Evening Express content can now be found on The Press and Journal website.When you purchased your subscription an email was sent to your account with your login details. To reset your password please use the following link.Please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team, on  Monday # Friday, am # pm, or email.Your subscription will continue as normal and all your existing subscriber benefits will remain in place. There are changes as to how you access your subscription benefits. See below, depending on what type of subscription you have.If you are an existing Evening Express Web subscriber, you can log in to your account as normal through The Press and Journal website.If you have an ePaper subscription you can access your ePaper on The Press and Journal website here.Or via a new link in your Daily ePaper email.There is no change to your reoccurring billing agreement. If you purchase a new subscription through The PJ website the price is subject to change and may be more than your current subscription. If you have any questions about your current subscription or how to access your subscription benefits in the future, please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team, on   Monday # Friday, am # pm, or email.The new website is now live. If you navigate to the Evening Express website or have website links saved, you will be automatically redirected to The Press and Journal website.Yes. You will find all the content that you would have normally found at the Evening Express here.Our combined newsroom will deliver you all of the Evening Express content that you would expect from The Evening Express website, plus more! We will continue to bring you the very best local news, football insight and in-depth features, as well as your favourite Evening Express columnists. These can all be found on The Press and Journal website as well as live news # updated as it happens # breaking crime news and the latest from court. You can also find our very best content that was published originally on the Evening Express website. These articles will be marked as originally appearing on the Evening Express website.Some Evening Express content will be moved to The Press and Journal website. Your bookmarked links will automatically redirect to the corresponding page on The Press and Journal website.Yes, The Press and Journal and the Evening Express social pages will continue. We will curate content specically for our audiences through our Facebook, Twitter and Instagram channels. All articles will link to The PJ website.Your registration details that you set up on the Evening Express website will work on The Press and Journal website. Please log in to your account as normal via the top right hand corner of the website or with this link.If you have forgotten your login or password please click the password reset link and follow the instructions.Yes. All registered users can access  free articlesevery  days. Please note, this information is correct at the time of publication, however, DC Thomson reserve the right to change this in the future.No, you will no longer receive Evening Express branded newsletters. You will now receive Press and Journal newsletters. If you do not wish to receive these, click the #unsubscribe# link at the bottom of the newsletter email.The Press and Journal has a Web subscription available which will give you access to all content on site from The Press and Journal and the Evening Express. You can purchase a PJ Web or PJ ePaper subscription here: www.pressandjournal subscribeThe Evening Express ePaper subscription is still available for purchase here.If you need help deciding what subscription is best for you, our Digital News Subscriptions Team are standing by to help. The Press and Journal Web subscription will give you access to all content on site from The PJ and the Evening Express. You can purchase a Press and Journal Web or Press and Journal ePaper subscription here.If you have an existing Evening Express Web subscription then all your subscription benefits are now available on The Press and Journal site. You have access to a bigger and better website, with all your favourite Evening Express content plus more.If you need help deciding what subscription is best for you, our Digital News Subscriptions Team are standing by to help.
